editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Dumb Lady: Or, The FARRIAR MADE PHYSICIAN. As it was acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL. By John Lacy, Gent.
LONDON: Printed for Thomas Dring, at the White-Lyon, next Chancery-Lane end in Fleetstreet. 1672.

div.head: To the High-Born and most hopeful Prince, CHARLES, Lord Limrick, and Earl of Southampton.
div.p:
WHen I began to write this Dedication, my hand shook, a fear possest me, and I trembled; my Pen fell from me, and my whole frame grew disorder'd, as if blasted with some sudden upstart Comet. Such Awe and Reverence waits on Dignity, that I now find it fit for me to wish, I had been refused the honour of my Dedication, rather than undertake a task so much too great for me. How shall I excuse this bold and saucie fault? How shall my mean unworthy pen, render you your Attributes? Now I find presumption is a sin indeed. I have given my self a wound beyond the cure of common men: Heal me then, Great Sir, for where Princes touch, the Cure is infallible. And now since you so graciously have received my Farriar, who dares say he is no Physician? When you vouch safe to call him Doctor, he has Commenced, and from your Mouth he has taken his Degree; for what you say, is, and ought to be: such a power is due to you from the Greatness of your Blood: I, and my abject Muse had perisht but for you; and in such distress, whither should we flee for shelter, but to him that has power to spread his wings and cover
us? and you have done it generously: Yet am I not to wonder at this Vertue in you, since your high Birth can do no less for you than to make you good, and you are so: and may that Goodness and Humility, which so early appears in you, increase to a full perfection: may your Vertues prove as beautiful as your person; may they still indeavour to out-vie each other, yet neither obtain, but still walk hand in hand, till your Vertues in you be reverenc'd by all Mankind, and your lovely Person honoured by all Women, and so may you continue to a long and happy life. But I need not wish this, nor the world doubt it; for already you're possest of all those Vertues, that men hereafter may reasonally expect from you: for being supported with Majesty of one side, and with so admired and beautiful a Mother on the other, besides her great and honourable Birth, on such sure foundations, you cannot fail our hopes, and that you never may, shall be for ever the prayers of

closer.signed: Your most faithful, and most obedient servant, John Laey.

div.head: The Epistle to the Reader.
div.p: GEntle Reader, (for so most Epistles begin) being conscious of my own weakness (for so they go on) I let thee know my own modesty had kept me from the Press, but for the importunity of friends, (and so they make an end.)

By this you see, Poetry consists more of Fancie than truth; so do the Poets too, or else, why should they seem ashamed to come into the Press? when I know their Bowels languish within them till they are there: Vain-glory being the chief ingredient, that makes up the spirit of Poetry, and the grand Inducement that puts us all in print. There is a kind of Charm in Poetry, 'tis like Tobacco and Chymistry; for if you once take the one, and undertake the other, you are fixt to the free-hold never to be parted. So fares it with the Dablers in the Dew of Pernassus: no revilings, no shameful reproaches can discourage us; still we write on, still we are fixt to the free-hold. I have observed, how much more precious to a Poet the Issue of his Brain is than that of his Loyns: for I have known them bury Children without grief or trouble; but the Issue of their Brain is so dear and tender to them, that if you go about to perswade them but to cut a Play or Poem shorter, they are so concern'd, that every Line you cut is valued at a Joynt, and every Speech a Limb lopt off Without doubt there is a kind of madness in Poetry, or else how can a man be so vainly possest as to think his own works exceed all other mens? That there are such men is but too true; for, I my self have thought so of my own Poetry: and when I that am so mean an under-shurb do prove so vainly mad, the tall Cedars sure must needs be shaken with out-ragious fits; and in those fits they write raptures, and fly to
the Skies, and get among the Gods, and makes such work, that you would swear they'r all breaking up School, and coming down amongst us. For my part, I wonder they have not come all this while, I'm sure they have been sufficiently provoked. I thank my incapacity I am not so far gone in Poetry as to arrive at those fits; yet I have this to say, that I have had my ends upon Poetry, and not Poetry upon me: for if Poetry had gained its ends on me, it had made me mad; but that I having my ends on it, appears in my getting money by it, which was shewn plentifully on my Poets days; but that I thank my friends for, and not the desert of my Plays: and I wish, Reader, that you may prove as kind to the Printer, as you were to me, when you were a hearer; and that my Farriar may prove as good a servant to him, as formerly to me, who am, Reader,

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: HEre I am, and not asham'd who know it,
I humbly come your Forma paup'ris Poet:
Not Hector-like, that one half-year has writ,
And fights th'other half to defend that wit:
Nor have I brought you here a second Play,
Like him that pretends preaching twice a day;
And when you gravely come i'th' afternoon,
He puts you off with repetition:
Saying, you may remember in the morn
I told you thus, and so, and where, and when;
So spins out his hour with the same agen.
Though such things pass on those that Sermons hear,
It will not do with Play-judgers, I fear;
I would you had their grace, and they your wit,
Sermons would then be hard as Plays to hit;
And easie Scenes would pass upon you, when
Grace above Wit abounds in Gentlemen.
How would the Poets all rejoyce to see
This age appear i'th' old simplicity;
To have your wives and you come ten times o'er,
To see the pudding eaten in Jane shore;
To cry up the bold Beauchamps of the Stage?
There was a blessed understanding age.
I would you were such but for one three days,
Till the poor Poet gather up his Bayes;
Or else my less than fifth-rate wit I find
Will force me beg you'l not be just, but kind:
Yet use me as you please, my comfort is,
If by your vengeance I must needs be worried,
I'm not the first small Poet has miscarried▪

list.item: Olinda His Daughter, pretending dumbness, and after that madness.
Leander Her Lover, but not permitted.
Drench A Farrier beaten to a Doctor.
Nurse His Wife, and House-keeper to Gernette.
Mr. Othentick A Parson, and Brother to Leander.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: THe like was never heard of, to have a sweet young Lady as she was going to be married, to fall dumb.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: If my wife had done so too, I think it had been ne'er the worse for the Common-wealth: but it would make any woman dumb to be designed for such a Fopp as Squire Softhead.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He is a fopp of a new stamp, I would not marry a milkmaid to him.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I would he had my wife, or any that would make him a cuckold: he has turned away twenty servants because they do not call him Squire oft enough: I shall be sick every time I hear the word Squire, he has made it so ridiculously loathsome.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He has been called so from his Cradle in the Country, where the title of Squire had always great worship, till the fool crept in amongst them, of which he is chief.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Yes Faith, for if there were an Army of Fopps (as truly I think they might be raised here) Squire Softhead must be General; he has one faculty, he will maintain a quarrel within three words of striking, and then he will eat cold Custard.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Hang him; but dost thou think my young Mrs. is dumb indeed?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: You saw the Doctors could not cure her, but if she do counterfeit do not blame her, for 'twere pitty upon pitty that the Sqr. (a Pox Sqr. him,) should have her; here they all come.

div.stage: Enter old Gernette, his daughter lead by servants as dumb, Sqr. Softhead her suitor, Nibby and Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: To have my Child struck dumb, upon her intended Wedding day, and to have the Doctors give her over too; O my unhappy stars!

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Are the stars such unhappy things, are they the cause of her dumbness? by the heart of a horse if I thought so I'd complain of 'em.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Complain of the Stars! who would you complain too Good Sqr. Softhead?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I'd complain to the Sun and Moon, I warrant you they'd not uphold them in their Raskally twinkling Tricks.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Alas poor Sqr. the Sun is always in haste, he ne'er stays to hear complaints.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why then I'l watch them when they fall, and if the proudest star of them all light within my ground, by the heart of a horse I'l have an Action of Trespass against them, and if the Law once take hold of 'em, I'l warrant 'em for twinkling again in haste.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: You were best get a star-trap to catch 'em in.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I warrant you a Law-trap will do as well.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Do you think your daughter had not better be dumb and dead, than marry such a ridiculous bruit as this?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O but his estate lies so sweetly round mine, that when she understands the blessing, she'l dote of him as I do.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Marry the Devil dote on him; why sir, he never comes into her Chamber, but he is all of a foaming sweat, throws off his Periwigg, and no one knows whether he or that smells rankest; then he runs to the Looking-glass, rubs his head with the dressing cloth, puts on his Periwigg, then combs out the Powder upon his Mrs. so makes a scurvy leg, and leaves her—there's a lover with a Pox to him. But Sqr. why do you prophane the stars so?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p:
Prophane? there's a company of vagabond wandring
stars that doe nothing but run up and down the sky to tell fortunes, just like our Gipsies i'th' high-way, I know 'em well enough. Heart of a horse, to lose a wife for want of three words, if she had said but to have and to hold, we had had no farther use of her tongue as I know of.

sp.speaker: Hib.
sp.p: Why so, Sqr.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Do not call me Sqr. Mrs. bare Sqr. without Softhead sounds scurvily, and 'tis scurvily done to call me so, and as scurvily I take it, and by the heart of a horse if you were not a woman, I'd wound you scurvily.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Truly methinks there's such a sympathy betwixt Sqr: and Softhead, that 'tis a thousand pitties to part them.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: I beseech you Sqr. which is the Ancientest family, the Softheads or the Haufheads?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: The Softheads are the Ancientest family in Europe, for Adam's youngest Son got a knock in his Cradle, and the Softheads ever since derive themselves in a direct line from him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How does my child? thou hast thy health I hope.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: A a a a a a.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Heart of a horse, I believe she counterfeits dumbness: but I have a trick to make her speak again if you'l give me leave.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir, what is it?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why I'l go call her Jade and Whore, and that will provoke her to call me Rogue and Raskal, you know.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Tho' it be upon such rude terms, I would be glad to hear her speak, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Come on: Why do not you speak the words of Matrimony, you Jade, that you might be my Wife, you little Whore? Look you Sir, she has given me an answer.

div.stage: Shee takes him a cuff o'th' ear.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I, but 'tis but with her hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: However 'tis an answer Sir, and she may marry me with her hand as well as with her tongue, for it seems to me to be the stronger confirmation.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Squire, if you love my child, endeavour to find all possible helps: where's my Servants? Run and ride all ways imaginable, leave no ground unsearcht, nor means unthought of to recover her.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: And good Sqr. Softhead, find out a wise man to cure her: do you know one when you see him?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: By my troth to my knowledge I never saw a wise man in my life.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Do you send a fool to find out a wise man?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: If he cannot find a wise man, a wise man will find out him quickly.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come lead my Child to her Chamber, and ride all ways and all Countreys to find out wise and able men.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Jarvis, how shall we do to know a wise man when we see him; what marks and signs have they?

div.stage: Exeunt all but Jarvis and Softhead.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, their dress and their speech they have from the stool of formality, and they have likely a bald head with a sattin cap on't, a narrow band, with a broad hat, a kain growing in their hands, with the silver head always bobbing at their lips, and they that are thus habited are taken for wise men.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why then I may be a wise man, if a Silver Kain will make me so; but prethee what do these wise men do?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Bi'rlady that will pusse a wise man to tell you; for I never heard of any thing that was wisely done in my life, therefore I think wise men do nothing.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Then I will be wise, whatsoever it cost me, for I love to do nothing above all things i'th' world: but come let us go the right way to find a wise man now.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I'l warrant you go right, for we'l go directly East.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why you fool, the wise men came out o'th' East, and dost thou think to find them there, when they left the place.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I, but Sir, they returned back into their own Countrey again.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Did they? why then the wise men of the East are not so wise as the wise men of France, for if they get into another Country, the Devil cannot drive them home again.

div.stage: Enter Drench a farrier, and Isabel his wife.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I say Dame Isabel I'l have it my way.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Have it my way? why, who are you, Sir? art thou any
more than my husband, fellow? how camest thou thus audacious then to say, I'l have it my way? say that again, and by the faith I have in my Confidant, my Gallant shall make thee an example.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: A ha, have you your Confidant and your Gallant, Wife?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes that I have. You know when the great ones have done with a fashion, it comes amongst we mean Madams into th'Country at last, and I have as much privilege due to me as any free born people in the world has, and we women will maintain the liberties of the she subject with our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Bi'rlady Wife you rant like a free born subject indeed: but pray you, what do you with the word free born subject.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I have it to shew that I am one of the free born, and may have my Gallant with all the perquisites belonging thereunto.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Why thou straglest as far out of the bonds of Matrimony as if thou'dst a good Jointure to justifie thee in't: there is a thing called duty Wife; the Parson you may remember said so when he married us.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I no more remember what the Parson said when he married us, than what he has said ever since when he preacht.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: The Jade's mad beyond recovery, a Pox of the liberty of the she subject: Wife there are five Children by the fire side, pray you how many of 'em's mine, Wife? I think 'tis high time to ask that question.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I must not be so much concerned with thee as to call thee husband, therefore Mr. Drench, the first child was yours.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And whose are the rest?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The rest are mine fellow, let that suffice thee.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And but one of them mine, Wife?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No but one yours, and for this following reason, after my first child you neglected your family duty, Mr. Drench, and when you grew negligent of me, I grew careful of my self, and from that care came the rest of my children, Mr. Drench.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p:
And those four children it seems, are free born subjects▪ I find a Wife a little modish, is worse than a Wife a little oldish:
Wife I'l downright poison your free born children.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O thou ungallantified Beast; wou'dst thou destroy thy own flesh and blood?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Not mine, but I will yours, Wife.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why, are not man and wife one flesh, and then are not your children mine, and mine yours, Mr. Drench?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Faith, I doubt this argument is the general security that mankind has to warrant their off-springs Legitimate.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Sirrah, talk of poisoning my children and I'l have thee so gallantified.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Gallantified? prethee what's that Wife?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To be gallantified, is to be soundly cudgel'd, sirrah: there is another point of she doctrine for you.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Pray you, let me ask you a question, Madam; nay be not ashamed to be called Madam, for as mean people as your self has the impudence to own it, therefore Madam are you true to your Gallant?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I, by my life am I, I else deserve to lose my privileges and be a bondwoman, I, and condemned to my own husband.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: That part of me that's Gentleman forgives thee freely for that; but the rough part, which is Farrier, must be reveng'd; & though your gallant carry your cudgel of love, I carry your cudgel of chastisement: I plead my privileges Wife, and must beat you: take this and that, and that and this.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Help, murther, murther, will you kill me you villain?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Kill you? alas this is but complement, Wife, and 'tis a new fashion come into the Country Wife, so I have it to shew you that I'm one o'th' free born Wife.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Murther, murther, help, murther.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: What's here, fie, fie, neighbour Drench, hold for shame: what, beating your Wife?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I marry is he Sir, what's that to you? suppose I long for a beating, I have been getting him in a good humour this two months to do it, and now you must disturb us.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Nay if you long for a beating I'm sorry I disturb'd you, I have done.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
You wicked fellow do you know what ye've done?
you have taken him off of the sweetest humour: I see by his looks I shall not get another blow of him to save my life.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: The jade is mad beyond all cure.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: I, for none but a mad woman would long for a beating, but farewell neighbours, I have done.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: You're an impertinent fellow to begin: Men that part rancounters are often kill'd or hurt, and therefore you ought Neighbour to be soundly cudgel'd.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Nay good neighbour hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You see he has taken off his anger from me, and now you must have all the sweet blows you raskal.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: So he shall, for if I had known thou hadst long'd for a beating, thou shouldst not have had a blow to've sav'd thy life, but you shall have it.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold; if ere I part man and Wife, if ere I put my hand betwixt the bark and the tree again, may my fingers bear fruit, and the boys rob my Orchard: A woman to long for a beating? what a blessing 'twere if all our Wives would long sol.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Now I know you long for a beating Wife, lest you should miscarry I'l beat you wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my longing is over indeed.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Is it? why then I'l to the Wood and drench a sick horse, and by that time I return I hope you may come to your longing again, and then I shall plead the liberty of the subject, and claw your free born sides again.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To be beaten thus! if I be not reveng'd, say I'm a woman without Gaul or invention; let me think a little, they say when a woman means mischief, if she but look upon her Apronstrings the Devil will help her presently; I'l try him: who is here?

div.stage: Enter Jarvis and Softhead to her.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: We may search long enough, the Devil a wise man that I can find or hear of.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I but Sir, you must know there be several sorts of wise men, and our business is to find out a wise Physician.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Either the Proverb's false, or the Devil's very dull, for
he has helpt me to no invention yet.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: But all the profess'd Doctors which we take to be wise Physicians have given her over you see.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I, but there may be skilful and wise men in Physick that do not profess it.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: You say very true, for I was cured once o'th' belly ach by an old woman and a warm Trencher, when all the Doctors i'th' Town had given me over.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: God a mercy Devil, I have it i' Faith, these Gentlemen have given me a hint for a revenge upon my barbarous husband: Gentlemen I overheard your discourse, and I find you are in great distress for a wise Physician.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: What then, does such a Countrey creature as thou know any thing that's wise?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I know not what your worship means by wise.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I dare swear thou dost not, for I that am a Squire scarce know my self.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But Sir I can help you to the most excellent Phisician upon earth, but then he's a man of the most strangest humours.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: 'Slid no matter for his humours, so he be wise; where is he?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why in that very Copse, blooding and drenching of a sick horse.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why, that's a wise Farrier, not a wise Physician woman.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But he is a famous Physician of Padua, and has retired himself on purpose to avoid Patients.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Then he is a fool and no Physician; for the wise Doctors never leave a Patient whilst he has either breath in's body or money in's purse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I but Sir, this is not a man that values money.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Then I say he is not a wise man. Come away Jarvis, this cannot be he we look for.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
Why you must know Sir, he exceeds the World for Physick, but then his humour is to deny his profession and acknowledge nothing but Ignorance; then Sir, he looks so like a
Farrier, that you would swear he were one indeed; then he is such a Clown.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: The greater the Scholar, still the more Clown; and the further he is gone in Learning, the more ignorant still in other things.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I, but is he far gone in Physick? can he make a dumb woman speak?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A dumb woman speak? I'll undertake he shall provoke a dumb divel to speak.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: That's the wise man I want: pray you where is he?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he is easily spoke with, but you'll find it wonderful difficult to get him to a Patient; neither gold, complement, nor other fair usage could ever yet work upon him, and yet there is a way to gain him.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Heart of a horse, pox to him, what way can that be?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: A way that you'll think strange, but very true: he could never yet be brought to a Patient without being rudely us'd and soundly cudgil'd to it.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Nay, by the heart of a horse, he shall want for no beating.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I marry, Sir, that will do it, and nothing else i'th' world; yet he will carry his seeming simplicitie so cunningly, that I hold a wager you come away perswaded that he is no Physician.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I hold a wager he shall own it, I'll make him commence Doctor else with a good cudgel, I warrant you: but is he such a rare Physician?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, but two days since he brought a mad woman to her wits again, that was suspected never to have any; nay, he has taken mens legs and arms off, and set 'em on sound again.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: That's beyond Surgeons-hall: sure he can conjure.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if this fellow be not a spie of the Vertuosos, and is come hither disguis'd to betray secrets in Nature.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: But does he take no other fees but beating Mrs?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Of a certain nothing else, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p:
I would some Doctors, I know, could be brought to
that, I would want no Physick, nor he should want no fees i'faith.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you'll find him in the wood with a leather Apron, and a Hammer by his side, as if he were a real Smith; and he studies as much to be a Farrier now, as formerly a Physician; and as his drink was altogether Wine before, now Farrier-like he studies all sorts of Ale, and drinks them soundly too: So, farewel Gentlemen, you'll find all things true as I have said, and my Raskal, I hope, will be cudgel'd from a Farrier to a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, this is such an humorous Physician, as yet I have not heard of.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Slid, we should have ask'd the woman one thing, it may be he delights to be beaten with one sort of cudgel more than another.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: We'll be so civil as to ask him that, if he puts us to it: But come, let us into the wood and find him out.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Hark, I hear the trees burl in the wood: Slid, here's a man coming towards us, I hope 'twill prove the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: By mass he has a leather Apron on, and a Hammer by his side.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: 'Tis he, what if we cudgel him before we speak to him?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Not for the world, Sir; that would be rude indeed. Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Save me, Sir? spare your Complement till I'm dying, and then I'll thank you for't.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: By the heart of a Horse I like him for that, for what should a man be saved for till he is dead, you know.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Sir, in short, we come (having business with you) to pay you all the respect and reverence that's due to your worship.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Respect, reverence and worship! you're very merry, Gentlemen: pray you, Sir, what part of me is it that you find worshipful?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: O Sir, it is your vertues that we admire.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Vertue! I never heard the word in my life, no nor the use on't.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Thou speak'st like an honest man, for by my troth I see no sign of vertue about thet.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Slid, you'll spoil all to be so blunt with him: Sir, we understand you are a great Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I understand my self to be a great horse Doctor, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: But pray you, Sir, be a man Doctor for my sake; by this cudgel it will be the better for you, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Sir, in short, we know you to be a famous Doctor of Padua, and we wish you would leave these abject thoughts of being a Farrier, and follow your own worthy profession of Physick.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Now you provoke me, Sir: do you think a Farrier inferiour to a Physician? he is the son of a Mare that thinks a horse has not as many diseases as a man.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: And he is the son of a whore that thinks a Squire has not as many diseases as a Horse: and Friend, take heed how you make comparisons, for you'll have all the Squires i'th' Country about your ears upon this score.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Country Squires I shall deal well enough with, and I shall justifie a Horse has more diseases than a Squire, and take the honour of Knighthood to help you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: You lye, and for the honour of Squire-hood I'll dye a virgin-Martyr.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, the latter end of a Squires argument is still quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Without quarrelling then I'll prove, that Squire and Squiress have more diseases than a Horse.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I, with the diseases of their own, that Nature never meant them, I grant you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: And first, I prove a Squiress, that is, a woman, may be dumb.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: And I answer, a horse cannot speak, set that against that: and yet I'll undertake to make a horse speak before you shall make a woman dumb, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Good Squire let us mind our business: In short, Sir, will you own your Profession? are you a Doctor or no?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p:
A pox of a Doctor, I am a down-right Farrier, I can give you a drench, or out you for the staggers when you'r drunk; I have no more learning than a horse: pray open my
head, and see if you can find a Physician there.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Since no means but the extremity will make you own your profession, we will cudgel you with as much complement as we can, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: A cudgel is but a course complement, I confess.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Hey, good boys i'faith, what a Devil mean you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Squire, do you strike the first blow.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: No, do you Jarvis, for the first blow will bear an Action, you know, and thou'rt a poor fellow, he can recover nothing of thee.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: What a Devil's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Fall on, fall on, will you confess you'r a Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold, I will be a Physician.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Will ye own, you are one, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I am one, I am one, hold, I am a very good Physician, I feel I am.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes, Gentlemen; he is a rare Physician, and would confess it too, but that he would not lose the pleasure of a cudgel, for once a week he longs for a beating: now you and I are even, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: A pox upon you, is this your design? I'll be reveng'd, you Jade, to the purpose: If I should say she is my wife, and that I'm a very Black-smith, they'd not believe me, 'twere but the way to be cudgel'd again.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Nay, come, Sir, what are you falling into a relapse again?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: No, no, hold, as the woman says, I am a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I, and so famous, that you can take off broken limbs and set them on sound again.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Well, I will own all this, rather than have my bones broken; and now I remember you fetch'd me once before out of this great wood, in Plato's great year, as my Master call'd it.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Pray you, Sir, how long is that since?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Why, next Strawberry-time, it will be compleat six and thirty thousand years.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Ho Boy!

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I, and I remember I poysoned somebody at your request.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: No, Sir, I do not remember that.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: But I do, Sir, by the same token you gave me a hundred pieces for a bribe tyed up in a laced Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I remember now as well as can be.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: But I do not remember I hired him to poyson any body, nor do I remember I'm six and thirty thousand years old: A pox of your Plato's great year, and his little year too.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, remember, your Mistress will ne'er be cured else.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Nay, rather than so, I will remember any thing.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Look you there, Sir, you see we both remember, therefore I pray you go with us to cure a distressed Lady.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: My business in Physick is killing, not curing, I assure you; for as there is your Man-taylor and your Woman-taylor, so there is your killing Doctor, and your curing Doctor, distinct Professions, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: But, Sir, you must own curing, as well as killing, or else we shall court you with a cudgel again.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: As we did in Plato's great year, you know Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I do not rememher that ye beat me then.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: But I remember it, by the same token you gave me my laced Handkerchief back, when you had put the Gold in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Now I do remember, hold, hold, [Offers to beat him. I do own curing; and since there is no remedy, I confess I am a Doctor: but if all menshould take their degrees, as I have done, we should have but small commencements. I once served a Mountebank, and have some of his canting terms, and for ought I know may prove as good a Physician, as if I'd served an Apprenticeship at Padua. Well, Gentlemen, what disease is it I must cure?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: You must help a Lady that is dumb, and has lost her speech.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p:
How, dumb, and lost her speech too! that's a great work; if she had only lost her speech, I could have cured her, or if she
had been but dumb; but to be dumb and speechless too, her case is very desperate, would I'd my wife and all the neighbourhood at that lock.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: But we must intreat your utmost skill, for 'tis a sad thing for a woman to be speechless.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: I, and dumb: but 'tis a sadder thing for a man to be a fool, for certainly he is a changeling that has a dumb wife, and would have her speak again: Are you in love with a womans sting?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why do you call it a sting, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Because, Sir, a woman has no tongue, they'r tongues in mens mouths, but they'r call'd stings in women.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: But, Sir, this Lady never spoke an angry word, not so much as to a servant.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: But she will do, if I cure her, for I've an unluckie hand that way; yet for her sweet dispositions sake I'll preserve her; and now I'll answer to the name of Doctor, with as much confidence, as a Quack drest up in all his ignorance.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Will ignorance make men confident? Slid, would I'd a little ignorance too.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I, if you had but a little 'twere very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Let me see how to behave my self like a Doctor now; I will first take your Mistress by the pulse, and look up gravely at the sieling all the while; then ask what she took last, and when she'd a stool, and there's half a Doctors work; then I'll prescribe something that will neither do hurt nor good, so leave her to luck, and there's the other half of the Doctor; then (to amuze the people) I'll give her the powder of a dryed Dock-leaf, with Apothecaries hard name to it; and if that will not mend her, I'll give her a drench, for women have sturdie stomachs, and why not as strong of constitution as Horses?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Heart of a horse, thou'rt a delicate mad Doctor; Sirrah, wilt thou give her a drench?

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Why, a drench is a potion, and a potion is a drench; only the distinction is, when you put it into a horn, then 'tis a drench for a horse; and when you put it into a vial-glass, 'tis a potion for a man; nay, I'll discover all their cheats.
sp.l: Come my Squire Softhead, never fear thy wench,
She shall be cur'd by Learned Doctor Drench.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Gernette, Softhead, Jarvis and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: ANd is he so famous a Physician, say you?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why, Sir, Aesculapius, as you call him, is a meer Mountebank to him.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I, and that fellow Galen Hippocrates, as you call him, not worthy to be his Apothecary: he can conjure, for he'll cure a wooden leg, make it flesh and bloud, and set you up sound again.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Nay, if he like your pulse, he'll give you a lease of your life for term of years.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I would he would give me three lives in mine, and begin them all at fifteen again.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Is not one life sufficient to make a man a Cuckold? but you'd have three to do it in.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Yes, because I'd make thee a Monster, that my child and I may live upon shewing thee.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You talk of wonders, I long to see him.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: He is i'th' next room, Sir, but 'tis the maddest Doctor, and of the strangest humours.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: So he is, for by the heart of a horse we were fain to bribe him with a cudgel, before he would own being a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A down right Sirreverence of a Doctor, I say get her a worthy husband, and say I told you so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You'r a foolish woman, and talk of that you understand not.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Understand not? sure I should know what a woman wants as well as you: I say again, a pox of your Doctor, get her a good husband, a plaister of true love clapt to her will do her more good than Sena or Rhubarb.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Did I not provide her a good husband? was she not to marry the Squire here?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A precious morsel of him: how came you to be a Squire with a pox, with your softhead, and your little head, and your no head at all?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Bear witness, she says I have no head at all.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Thou mayst take it, and throw it to the dogs for any brains there's in't.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I will not call you whore, Gentlewoman; but by the heart of a horse your husband's a cuckold; and he is not only an English cuckold, but also an Italian cuckold; that is to say, he is a cuckold both before and behind.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Sirrah, cudgel him, or lie in the truckle-bed all thy life.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I'l rather cudgel thee, for I believe every word he says.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: For shame proffer her a husband of her own chusing, let her have Leander.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She shall never be his Hero.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: If she perish in the Hellespont, at your peril.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Hellespont? how came you by that fine word?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Honestly enough.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: As honestly as you came by your child, I think.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I have seen Mr. Hellespont in a Puppet-show, and Hero, and Leander too.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Talk no more of Leander, I know him not; but who e'er he be, he is not to be compared with the Squire here for wealth.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Is your Squire boobe, loobe, poope, to stand with Leander for parts and person?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Do you know his parts?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, but I have heard of him and his parts.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Grant me patience, for I have much ado to forbear calling you whore, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Do if thou dar'st; is wealth to be named the same day with love? I scorn that comparison, though I'm o'th' wrong side o'th' teens i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Hast thou any sense of the fopperies of love left?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Dost thou call sweet love foppery? though thou'rt my Master, thou'rt a beast; go, go to bed and die, what dost thou in this world? let the Doctors give him Physick, no bodie else has need on't.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: You'r very bold with your Master, wife.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: He has been as bold with me, let that suffice you husband: I have so fresh in my memory the sweet effects of love, that I wonder mankind should be such beasts as to forget it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Go give your child suck, for that's your talent, and meddle no more.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: That's another sign 'tis none of my child, for why should he be so careful to have the child suck, if it were not his own?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Look you friend, your wife has abus'd me, and 'tis not civil to call her whore to her own face: but I tell thee to thy face, she is a Whore Rampant, and in Heraldry thou'rt a Cuckold Passant.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I, Sir, and my wants make me a Cuckold Couchant, or I'd ne'er indure it.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Oh, here comes our delicate humoursome Doctor i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Squire, go bid them make my Daughter ready to receive the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I do not care to go, for she has her wild Irish Chamber-maid that always calls me Squire pogemihone, and then laughs at me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray you go, Sir. You'r very welcome, Sir, I have very much desired to see you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Hippocrates says, I pray you be cover'd.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray you, in what Chapter of Hippocrates does he bid you be cover'd?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: In the first chapter of keeping your head warm.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A pleasant Gentleman, and I love his humour. But, Sir, concerning my Daughter who is very sick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am very glad on't, Sir, and I would you and your whole Family were sick, lame or blind, that I might have the honour to cure you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, this is the strangest Doctor: he had need of good parts to bear out his humours.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And now, Sir, I pray you what's your Daughters name?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Olinda, Sir, at your service.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Olinda? a pretty name to be cured.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sir, I'l see if my Daughter be ready to come forth to you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir: and what woman is that, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: The Nurse of the house, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Bi'rlady, a pretty piece of houshold-stuff, and a fine ornament for a Couch: I do salute you Nurse, and I would I were that happy sucklin, that shall draw down the milk of your favour and affection, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Her pulse beats not thereabouts, Sir: hands off, for she's my wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, Sir, I congratulate you for having so handsome a wife, and your wife for having so worthy a husband: Your breasts, sweet Nurse.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Pray you hold, Sir, half this courtesie would serve.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Worthy Sir, I cannot declare enough how much I'm your servant. Delicate breasts, Nurse.

div.stage: His hands upon her breasts still▪

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: O Devil take you, Sir, let my wives breasts alone.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sweet Sir, I must see her breasts, it is the Doctors duty to look to the Nurses milk.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: You shall not look to her milk, I'll look to your water for that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Jar.
sp.p: Sir, my wife is not with child.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But she must be with child: what sayst thou Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: If your worship think it be for my health, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou wilt dye in a week else.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Do you hear that?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: A pox of your Mountebanking, Sir, my wife is sound and well, and shall have no Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, I know you'r a man of sence, and I beseech you hear reason. A sweet Nurse!

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O dear Doctor.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: A pox of your sence and reason, give me my wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But, Sir, I'm from home, and want a woman; I hope you'l be civil to a stranger; if you come my way, I'l be as kind to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: The Devil take your kindness, give me my wife.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Give me a reason for't; for look you, Sir, your wife is either with child, or else she has a tympany. Nurse, shew me your legs, they may be swell'd and dropsical, a sweet woman may be cast away here for want of a little looking to.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Let my wives legs alone, or I'l downright thrust you out o'th' Room.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, I find you'r cholerick, but I'l give you a purge shall make you so patient, that if you saw me lye with your wife, you should not have so much gaul left, as would make an angry line in your face.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Now good husband take Physick.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: God a mercie Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, he is always so fretful, and so cholerickly jealous.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I'l make you an example.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Such another word, and I'l put thee into a Fever, and keep thee in't a year; I tell thee fellow, thy wife is not well, and I will give her a gentle gentile Glister; prethee be sick Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I am sick, and, if you please, you shall give me a gentle gentile, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: You are no more sick than I am huswife.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Sure the Doctor knows better than you or I whether I be sick or no; and I find I am sick, and I do so long for a gentle gentile, what d'ye call it.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: My Master is coming, or I'd give you such a gentle gentile.

div.stage: Enter old Gernette, his Daughter lead in by Servants, and Sqr. Softhead.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sir, I have brought my Daughter, and I beseech your best care of her, for the world's gone with me if she die.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, people do not die so easily without the help of a Physician.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A notable Droll, and puts me in great comfort.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Is this she? a very pretty Patient, and one a man may venture on in sickness, or in health: come on, Sir, let me feel your pulse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am not sick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But your Daughter is, therefore give me your pulse; why, by your pulse, I find your Daughter is dumb.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O dear, how he hits on't!

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Hits on't? you'd be hit on't too, would you; he may thank his knowing on't before.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But, Sir, 'tis strange that you should know my Daughters disease by my pulse.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sympathy does it: I find you have no faith here in the Sympathetical Powder, therefore cannot know our Sympathetical way of practice; when any man or woman is sick in Greenland, they always send the next of kin to the Doctor, and by that pulse the disease is known, and the Patient cured.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Pray Doctor feel whether I be dumb or no.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Let me feel your pulse husband; O I am sick, and the Doctor must physick me, or I die.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: The Devil has found a new way to make a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But what may be the cause think you of her dumbness?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, Sir, according to the sence of Aristotle.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Aristotle was a Philosopher, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I, and a Physician too, I know what I say. Heart! I had like to have been gravel'd; I say again, according to the sence of Hippocrates.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I marry, Sir, he was a Physician indeed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I, and a Philosopher too, therefore no matter which of their opinions I take.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: By my troth I think so too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And therefore as I said at first, according to the sence of Aristotle, women are dumb because they cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A sweet Doctor, I always thought so indeed.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Have you tasted of his sweetness you quean?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Not yet, but I hope I shall do, you rogue.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But, Sir, are there many reasons for dumbness in a woman?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Several, Sir: a woman may be dumb, when she has no mind to speak, and she may speak when no body has a mind to hear her; this is Natural Philosophy now.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, you speak, as if it were sullenness in their Sex, and not a defect in Nature, nor other accident.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I do so: in some Romance perhaps you may have read of a womans being dumb; but sure no man seriously ever heard of a woman that could not speak.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: He is i'th' right i'faith; this is the Doctor of Doctors i'faith.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Again the Doctor? I would he were hung about thy neck.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: By my troth, so would I to determine thy jealousie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But pray you, Sir, why should you think a woman cannot be dumb?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, your men that has indeavour'd to find out the perpetual motion, has come near it, I confess, with their Clocks and Pendulas: but Aristotle says, Fix a Dya ••
plate to a womans mouth, and if the perpetual motion be not there, let them never hope to find it; and if it be there, 'tis infallible a woman cannot be dumb.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Squire, forsooth, here is a Letter.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p:
A good Boy; Squire, and forsooth does well together,
they'r very suitable; but hold, this Letter is not big enough to have business in't, nor little enough to be a challenge. Heart of a horse, a down-right challenge; [Reads the Letter. and if he be as stout as Hercules, I'll fright him out on's fighting, or he shall fright me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But touching the cause of my childs disease, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, you must know, her dumbness may proceed from the string-holt.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The string-holt? why that's a disease one of my Horses has now in the stable.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I grant you, Sir; but we of Padua call a lameness in the tongue the string-holt, from that very string which you call the greedie worm: (A pox on me, I shall betray my self a Farrier:) and this dumbness proceeds from a contraction, [Aside. or shrinking of that Nerve or String; which shrinking proceeds from Stomachous fumigations which proceed from certain Exhalations, or Influence of the Stars, call'd in Arabick; do you understand Arabick?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Not a word, not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: A Gentleman and not speak Arabick? why, where have you been bred?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I neither speak Arabick, Latin, nor any language, but my mother tongue.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What blessed luck is this for me? how shall I do to explain it to you then? for Optimun purgamentum, cantaridem, venetreclum, do ye conceive me, Sir; Vinum cum drammum, scirramoucha scrupulum; and this is just your Daughters case, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Ho boy, Doctor, he claws it away with Latin i'faith.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Still commending the Doctor? you'd have him claw you away with Latin too, would you not, you Jade?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I faith, or with Greek either, you knave.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sure he's a Learned man, if one could understand him; pray you, if you please, state her case in English.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Why, this is worse than all the rest; why, you must know, Sir, that the vapours passing from the right side where
lyes the heart, unto the left where lyes the liver, the lungs, which in Latin we call Armion, having communication with the brain, which in Greek we call Nazmathon, by Intermedium of the Venacava, which in Hebrew we call Rabshack, and in Arabick Helgoshob.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Thou beast, when wilt thou know Rabshack and Helgoshob? O most divine Doctor!

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Divine? is it come to Divinity now? why then you hope to be saved by him.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I'l venture with him into Rabshack and Helgoshob, what e'er befals me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Ragshag? Sir, I understand these tongues less than Latin.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'm sorry for't, Sir; did you but know the sweet sound of Hebrew and Arabick, you would never speak your mother-tongue again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
Doct.
sp.p: How shall I answer this? pox on him, he makes me sweat. Why, Sir, it is true, that in time of health the heart lyes on the left-side, and in most diseases too: but in dumbness, the heart by some strong passion being turned, and whirled to the right-side, till by art it be returned and whirled back to the left, neither man nor woman can possibly speak; and that is the positive cause of all dumbness.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O dear Doctor, I cry still.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Is it come to dear Doctor now? is he your dear, you whore?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: He is not yet, but he shall be you cuckold.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Cuckold? remember this.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I do remember thou art one, and I will remember to continue thee so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sir, I am well satisfied; now, if you please, let us proceed to the cure of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
O, there's the point; why, there be several ways to cure, and twice as many ways to kill; for we Learned Physicians
with too much studie, have likely a worm in our heads, and when that worms wrigles, the mind alters; so that we change our fashions as much in Physick, as the Court and Gentry do their cloaths: But come, get my Patient to her bed, and when she's warm, give her a lusty dose of Sops and Wine.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How, Sops and Wine! sure that will make her drunk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The better, Sir; for when people are drunk, they are apt to speak their minds: I work by Natural Causes: you see by the vertue of Cakes and Wine how women tattle at a Gossoping; no man ever knew a dumb woman at a Christening or a Gossoping, but she talkt before she went away.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: The Doctors i'th' right, I'l be sworn, I know it by experience: O brave Doctor.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Brave Doctor, i'faith proclaim your love with him.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: By my troth so I will, with the first opportunity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: So lead her to bed, and let Nurse drink with her to countenance her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I will indeed, Mr. Doctor, I will be sure to obey your commands.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And when you have drunk smartly, bring me word how it works Nurse.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: You shall be hang'd first, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And be sure Nurse come alone still, for you know she may have something to say to me, that is not fit for her husband to hear.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: A pox on you, must my Master pimp for you too.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray you take your fee, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By no means; no cure, no money with me, Sir: but pray you be careful of my Patient, and be sure to send Nurse still to me.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I must be a Cuckold, and cannot avoid it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sir, I shall send to you, but perhaps not Nurse.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: So, my Master is jealous of her, as well as I; now 'tis plain he got my child; how many points o'th' Compass am I a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I hope I shall make that Rogue mad for beating me.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Your servant Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Your servant Nurse.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Boy, did Squire Softhead receive my note so cheerfully?

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and withal he told me, he wonder'd that he heard not sooner from you, being you know he was to marry your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Is he so brave? I shall the better digest my ruin, if I find honour in him, yet he with all his merits can never deserve her; 'tis strange if he should fight, for they say he is a very ass. O here he comes.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Sirrah, yonder he is, will you be sure to do as I bid you?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Yes, I warrant your worship.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Just when you see my vest off, that's your time.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: I'll be sure to do it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Dam you, Sir; why? why the pox save me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Because your poor servant hath an occasion to kill you, and send you to heaven. But why Dam me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Because your poor servant hath an occasion to kill you, and send you to hell, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This is uncharitable language, from a dying man, as you are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I scorn dying, I've an estate will keep me alive in spight of a Duel, Sir: I scorn but to be very charitable. Where wilt thou be buried fellow?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Let me be kill'd first, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Nay, by the heart of a horse, doubt not that, Sir; and if you'l have a Tomb-stone over you, write your Inscription, and my Stone-cutter shall do it: Nay, I scorn but to be charitable, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Good rich Squire make your will, for dye you must.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: What a pox should I kill thee for, that has nothing to leave me for my pains?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Now you are not civil, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I scorn but to be as civil as any man.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You shall find me so too, for I'l see you buried in the flaxon your Grandam spun her self, and left your worship for a winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: And I'l be as civil to you, Sir; for I'l see you buried in Flannil: and, Sir, to shew my self civil, if you have a mind not to fight at this weapon, I'l stay till you chuse another; nay, if you have a mind not to fight at all, for civilities sake, I'l have no mind to fight at all neither; I scorn to be behind hand in civility.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Now no more words, Sir, but strip and take your fortune.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Pull off Boy: and, Sir, I must have you know, that I long as much to go out of this world honourably, as you to stay in it honourably.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: This is my Q. I take it.

div.stage: [Softheads Boy runs away with his Masters sword.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: And to shew you, I kill you, Sir, meerly upon honour, and not upon malice; I lovingly imbrace you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Imbrace an Ass: leave your Fencers tricks, and take you to your sword, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Then a pox on you, Sir; and give me my trusty sword boy: how! the rogue is run away, and with my sword too: why sirrah, raskal, come back you treacherous rogue; come this must be your plot, Sir, to hire my boy to run away with my sword, Sir: Why rogue, traytor to my honour, come back.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This shall not serve your turn Squire, my boy shall run and overtake him, I'l warrant you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I scorn to be beholding to you, or your boy, Sir; I'l run and overtake him my self, Sir; and I charge you upon honour to stay till I come back, Sir.

div.stage: [He runs off as fast as he can.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p:
This is the newest coward I have known, he has cozen'd me; for as I live, I thought he would have fought, for he bore it up to the very point of danger: Sirrah, theres a Vest
〈◊〉 you, and run after him, and cudgel him, till he be all over black and blew.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: You could not have put me upon a better imployment, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, I was looking out at my window, and as I thought saw a Duel towards, so I came.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: To prevent it?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No by my troth, Sir, my business is not to prevent wounds, but to cure 'em; where is the other that fought you? Nounze you have made quick dispatch; have you kill'd him and buried him already?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, he is gone very safe, and no wound about him, but that of his honour.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Was it not Squire Softhead, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: It was so, Sir; and how he has behaved himself, you shall know anon. But, Sir, I guess you are the Doctor that undertakes the Dumb Lady.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You'r happily come, Sir; for I have earnest business with you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why I? the dulness of your eye shews you have, let see, let see, a very dangerous and high flying pulse.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I am not sick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You are loth to confess; come I see you have a clap, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: By my honour, not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Do not let it go too far, modesty has spoil'd one half of the Town-Gallants, and too much confidence the other half; so that there's no hopes of any of you.

sp.speaker: Lea.
Doct.
sp.p: I have heard of a Naval Knight, called Sir Hero Leander; are you the man I pray you?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You are merry, Sir, but my affair is serious; you have a dumb Lady your Patient, to whom I am a servant and she, Sir, has an equal love for me: now being by her father barr'd of all means of coming together.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You would have me do it, and so pimp for you.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Not pimp, Sir; but I would fain oblige you to befrend us.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Befriend us? a modest phrase for pimping; I begin to find that physick is but one part of a Doctors trade, and I shall gain the Character of Chaucers Semstriss; for says he,
sp.l: She keeps a shop for countenance;
So I shall physick give for countenance;

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, I know you may bring me to the speech of her: I mean no pimping, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Whatever you mean, the thing is the same, Sir; for how can I help you to the speech of her, but I must bring you together? and if I brng you together, what's that but pimping, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But I mean in the way of honesty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Honesty? indeed I have heard 'twill make men rich and brave; but I never heard of honesty in the case before: Sir, the profession will not bear it: and would you make a pimp of a Physician? O most horrible indignity!

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Pray you, Sir, be pacified, and let this shew you that I can be grateful.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Is there a fee belonging to that [Gives him a purse. part of a Doctor too? I begin now to think that pimping is no such scandalous thing as malicious men report it. Sir, you have given me such strong reasons to think so well on't, that I believe none rail at it, but such as would be glad of the imployment themselves: And, Sir, as you call it, I will help you to the speech of her, or befriend you, or pimp for you.

sp.speaker: Lea.
Doct.
sp.p:
I knew there was some trick in't, 'twere impossible else, either by Nature, Art, or misfortune, a woman should be dumb▪ for take a womans tongue, and pluck it up by th'
roots, I'm sure in an hour another would grow i'th' room on't, But come, Sir, you shall shift you, and pass for my Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: That I think an excellent way, and nothing better.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: We cannot miss to cure her now, I shall get credit as I am her Physician, and money as I your bringer together, or your pimping friend.
sp.l: Thus shall I be your Advocate and Protector,
And venerably call'd both Baud and Doctor.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Doctor, Leander like an Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: THis habit will pass me for an Apothecary, I only want some of their canting phrases.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, faith you are as well qualified for an Apothecary, as I am for a Physician; you have trusted me with your heart, and now I'l trust you with my simplicity: I am no Doctor, but was forc'd to own being one; why, and how, I'l tell you hereafter; but having served a Mountebank, that and my great share in impudence, has made me famous.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Is it possible impudence should have such vertuous effects?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yes, yet some men rail at impudence, and speak it vitious, when the Jest is, they that rail most at it, make most use on't: 'tis doubtless the greatest blessing in the world, and most men do their business by it.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But if you be so ignorant, sure impudence should not bear you out, especially in this learned Profession.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O, Sir, it is the securest cloak for ignorance of all Arts: other Professions are lyable to miscarriages and questionable: but the Physician may kill from the Fool to the Senator, from the Beggar to the Bloud-Royal, and ne'er be call'd in question; the dead was never so uncivil yet, as to come out o'th' other world to complain of the Physician.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign they'r civily us'd where they are: But do you not studie at all?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: It needs not, for the great studie of Physick is come to nothing now but letting Bloud; and it falls out well for me that am a down-right Farrier.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: How, is your real Profession a Farrier?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yes faith, and with the same Fleams I let Horses bloud▪ I use my Patients to; and the horses drench is the potion I give to men, and I cure more than I kill; so that I am the only Doctor that has found out horse and man to be of one constitution.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But how comes letting of bloud so much in fashion?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O, Sir, 'tis Alamode Paris; if your corn does but ake against rain, what says the Doctor? Let him bloud: Nay, if you be troubled in Conscience, they'l let you bloud for that too

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: They let not bloud for the Small-pox, I hope.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But they do; and 'tis the opinion of Padua, that 'tis as sure a way to kill, as an old woman and Saffron is to cure.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: How came you by that Velvet Coat?

div.stage: Enter a Seamans wife, a Country-man with an Vrinal, and an Apprentice with an Vrinal, with other Patients.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O here come Patients; mark [They press to the Doct. my confidence: good people one at once, let the woman be served first: Now woman what want you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That that no bodie can help me to, the worse luck, Sir; I am a Seamans wife, Sir, that has been married this dozen years, and I have never a child, and please you, and I would fain have a child, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And would'st thou have me get it?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would fain have your worship give me something that will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By my troth I have nothing about me at this time can do it: Why, look thou send thy husband to Sea, that often make the wife fruitful.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A lack, Sir, I have tryed all ways both by Sea and Land, and nothing will help me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I do prescribe thee a lusty Wine-porter, and he shall be thy gallant.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And it please your worship, I have tryed your gallant, and your top-gallant, and your top and top-gallant, and all will do no good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By my troth, go try the main-yard too; and if that fail thee, thou'rt a barren woman of a certain: but come i'th' evening to me, after a glass of Wine I may have something to help thee.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And it please your worship, I am a poor man.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I have never a Medicine for that disease: Prethee be gone fellow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: My wife, and it please you, lies dangerously sick.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If thou be'st poor, trouble thy self no further, she'll dye of a certain: but art thou so poor thou canst not come to the point?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I would intreat your worship to visit her; and here's an old angel for you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: This is but one of the points, there's two and thirty in the Compass, fellow; however I'l come see her: she rules the roast when she has her health, does she not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I, but too much to my sorrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou hast a stable, hast thou not?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yes, and it please you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Count.
sp.p: Why, Sir? that's as I serve my horse when he is sick.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But I know thou'rt a hen-peckt fellow, and such women as do command in chief, I physick them as I do horses, and all little enough too: but first take her and ride her off on her legs.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: That's more than I and your worship to help me can do, Sir: But I hope your worship will come.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yes, yes. What are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: A Prentice, Sir, that has brought my Mrs. water, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Prent.
sp.p: Yes, and it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: How sure are you? did you see her make it?

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: I did not see her make it, but, and it please you, I heard her make it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, I find by thy Mrs. water friend, that thou art almost out of thy time.

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: Yes truly, within three months, and it please you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I knew it; why here is twenty visible things in this water; your Master is out of Town about a purchase, is he not?

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: Yes, and it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And you are removed out o'th' Garret to lye in the next room to your Mrs. to keep spirits from her, are you not?

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: By my troth, and so I am, and it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The water shews it plainly; hold, ha, I find your Mrs. is apt to dream much, and is frighted, and walks in her sleep, and comes to your chamber to be awakened, does she not?

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p:
By my truly, she has been so troubled with these frights since my Masters absence, that I have never had a good nights rest since he went; for she'l come in her sleep, and throw her self upon my bed; and then I lye as still as can be, and then she rises like a mad woman, and throws all the clothes off, and makes such work with me, that I'm
ashamed your worship should know it, then tell her on't the next day, and she runs away and laughs at me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I know her disease, commend me to thy Mrs; and tell her, because I'll make a perfect cure on't, I'l come and lye in the next room to her my self, and thou shalt go into the Garet again.

sp.speaker: Prent.
sp.p: And it please your worship, my Mrs. perhaps may not like that so well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: She will like it I know; 'tis variety must recover her, go tell her I'l not fail her.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Here comes Squire Softhead, that ran away with a trick to save his honour.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I see your boy has cudgel'd him to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Save you Doctor, a word in private, can you keep a secret?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis the first point of my Profession, secresie.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Dispatch that fellow out o'th' way quickly then.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: He is my Apothecary, and as much to be trusted as I am: But how came your face so?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Honourably of my side, you must know I have fought a Duel with a damn'd coward, a raskal call'd Leander.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Now must I be abus'd, and dare not take notice on't: But, Sir, is it possible Leander should be such a coward?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Do you know him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Is he your frend, Sir? if he be, I am sorry I said so of him, Sir; but if he be not your friend, he is a coward, and I'l justifie it, and a raskal, and I'll maintain it; yet, Sir, if you have the least relation to him, I shall be very ready to eat my words, rather than disoblige you.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, he is neither relation nor friend of mine, neither care I a farthing for him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Then he's the son of a whore, and I'l tell you how he served me: just when we were stript, and ready to go to it, the base raskal hired my boy it seems to run away with my sword.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That was base indeed.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I cannot believe so unworthy a thing of him.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Rather than offend any man; I'l say I hired my boy my self to run away with my sword, I can be no civiler, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Rather than so, I will believe Leander did it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you heartily, and I will justifie all that Mandevil or Coriat writ for your sake, so you believe it your self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But how was the Duel, if the boy ran away with your sword?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why, I ran after him, got my sword, and came honourably to him again, and I drive him honourably round the field; and all that while his boy got behind me dishonourably, and cudgel'd me damnably, that I am asham'd it should be known.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, it shall ne'er be known for us, but if the boy cudgel'd you behind, how came you thus black and blew before?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why, he beat my head and shoulders so divelishly, that it came quite through to th' other side, that my face is all over Coventrey blew: therefore good Doctor, report I am your patient and desperately wounded, and there's twenty pound, and I'l have a Red Scarf with a great fringe about my arm, methinks that looks valiantly; and here is a sword has been up to the hilts in bloud; and if you hear Leander be kill'd, not a word who did it on your lives.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Sir, to tell you true, we came just now from dressing of Leanders wounds; and to be plain with you, if you did it, your life is in danger; for he cannot live above two dressings more.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Therefore, if you would escape hanging, flee your Country.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Heart of a Horse, I did neither wound him, nor kill him.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, did you not confess just now you did? besides your sword is all bloudie up to the hilts, which will hang you, if there were no other witness in the world,

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Heart of a horse, I shall be hang'd with a trick of my own.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'l get money out of him; Sir, we can do less than send for a Constable and apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: O dear Doctor, thou wilt not be such a raskal, I hope.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'l be reveng'd of you for beating of me into a Doctor, when I had a mind to conceal my parts: therefore get me a Constable.

sp.speaker: Soft.
Lea.
sp.p: Why, how came your sword so bloudie?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: If you must needs know, 'twas with killing of a sheep, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: A sheep? why, are you not asham'd, as you are a Squire to own that?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: There's no shame in it, Sir; for 'twas a Ram-sheep, Sir, and he assaulted me; and in my own defence, I kill'd him honourably and fairly.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: This excuse will not serve, for Leander is dying, and we must apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Since you are such a raskal, I'l give you a hundred pound to conceal all that I have said.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Tell us the whole truth of your Duel, and give me two hundred pound, as you did for the last man you kill'd in Ploto's great year.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: A pox of your Plato, and your two hundred pound: but since there's no remedy, you shall have it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: And withal tell us the truth of your Duel, and we'l swear to be true to you.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why then by the heart of a horse we fought not one stroke, but my boy ran away with my sword, as I contrived it, and I seemed to run after him to fetch it again, and so ran quite out o'th' field. And this is the truth by the heart of a horse; then Leanders boy ran after me, and cudgel'd me, as you see, Coventrey wise.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, Sir, go into my chamber, and send for your money, and I'l release you, and keep your counsel faithfully.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: To give a Physician two hundred pounds, and not so much as one clap cured for it; O dishonour to true Squirehood for ever more.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Slid Pothecary, here is my wife, I'm [Enter Isabel. resolv'd I will not own the quean; for first she'l obstruct our design, next I owe her a revenge: Hark you, we must have some device to be rid of her.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I understand you very well.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Save your worship.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Would you speak with any body here woman?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Pray tell his Doctorships worship, that here's his wife.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Alas poor woman, his worship has ne'er a wife.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Who told you so? were you by when his worship was unmarried again? I must and will make bold to speak to him. Good Doctor dog-bolt, how long have you been worshipful?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Feel her pulse, feel her pulse Pothecary.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'l take you over the face, if you feel any thing about me, you beastly fellow.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Prethee be gone, woman; for I assure thee Doctor Drench has ne'er a wife.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But there is a horse Doctor Drench a Farrier that has a wife.

sp.speaker: Doct.
