sp.p: I, the Farrier Drench may have a wife; but I assure thee Doctor Drench has none, therefore be gone woman.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Are you too proud to own your wife, you ungrateful raskal? who made you a Doctor, but my invention and a good cudgel? I'l spoil your trade of physick, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now is your time Pothecary to be rid of her.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: 'Tis enough: But Doctor do you hear the strange news that's abroad?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: O lack, what news is it, I beseech you, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I do not speak to thee woman.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: It seems there is an Edict made, and it goes very hard with poor women, I confess,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Now good Sir, as ever you came of a woman, tell me quickly what it is.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I will not tell my tale to the woman.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Then tell me, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Why, Sir, there is a new Edict made, that no woman upon pain of death, under such a degree or quality, in all presume to have a gallant, or any man but her own husband.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: And all this upon pain of death? Slife, who would not be a rebel at this rate?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You say very true; and upon this hard usage, there are twenty thousand women in arms, and have made a formal Remonstrance, wherein they declare for the priviledge of the She-subject, and will live and die for the free-born women of England.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Ten thousand blessings upon them; where are they, I beseech you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: They'r drawn up upon Hounslow-heath, and are now marching to besiege Winsor Castle.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Though I sell all I have, and undo my children, I'l have a Regiment whatsoever it cost me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I saw the Cadge stand open by the Stocks, throw this purse into't, and say I sent it; and when she is in, lock the door, and bid the boys whoot at her, and call her baud, and then I am reveng'd for her beating she procured me.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I find the Doctor has a mind to gallant me, he has such a winning way with him, he swears 'tis a thousand pities such a raskal as my husband should e'er enjoy me, and such like fine terms, that 'tis hard I swear to withstand him: But yet ones honesty; why, I confess honesty's a fine thing to read of in a Romance: But I do not find the practice of it so followed, as to make it a fashion; therefore if Doctor's love hold, I shall, I shall, I cannot help it husband, I shall.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nurse, how happy am I to meet with thee alone? a rogue, methinks I could e'en run through thee now.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, so ye all say; but I am sure I could never see it yet.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now good Nurse grant me my suit.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Truly Doctor so I would, if it were not for my honesty.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou fool, there is no such thing as honesty: the word honesty is a meer bugbear that jealous husbands invented to keep women in awe with, as raw-head and bloudy bones frights children, that's all i'faith.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: But is it possible that should be true, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nurse, it is so true, that I'l shew thee a reverend book, called St. Aratines, where you shall be convinced, there's no such thing as honesty.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Say you so; nay then, dear Doctor, give me physick. Here comes my husband, what woman's that with him?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis a Patient of mine that has twenty diseases besides a Neapoliton pox.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: What disease is that Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis a new fashion'd disease came fresh with the last Packet.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Have we not old fashion'd diseases enough of our own, but we must send for new ones over?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: What a villain is this Doctor? first not to own his wife, next with a trick to trapan you into the Cadge; then make the boys throw dirt at you, and call you baud: But why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To think that ever I should live to be call'd baud; if he had call'd me whore, 'twould ne'er have vext me; but to be call'd baud, is to be thought an old woman unworthy of copulation.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Troth malicious people may call you baud, but I protest I think you far worthy to be call'd whore; therefore pray you wipe your eyes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I thank you for your good opinion howsoever.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: If it please you, Madam, I'l make my opinion good.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Here is a rogue to be jealous of his wife, and yet play the whore-master himself.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Look you, there's Doctor Devil for you that will not own his wife.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: And my wife with him, take no notice of them, I believe he has made me a Cuckold of all colours, of the red, and the green, the yellow, and the blew bed: A pox on him, faith be reveng'd, and make his caps too little for him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: By my gallant so I would, if it were not for my honour.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Honour? I'l not come near your honour, that's an ayrie thing, that lies i'th' crown of your head, my request lies lower quite another way.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Look, look, how familiar Doctor dog is yonder; O for revenge.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: A pox on him, I'm not able to indure this, go you in there: Are you in your closet, Sir? if you be, [Exit Isa. come out and see a fine sight quickly, Sir: O look, look this cursed Doctor.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: We had need be careful of our credits, Doctor; for the world is grown so base, that if they should but see a man and a woman in bed together, they would swear they were naught straight.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Fear nothing Nurse.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Look, look, look, I am no Cuckold to speak on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Is it so; what a false quean is this to use me thus?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Use you thus, Sir? 'tis use me thus, with your favour; Slid, why are you concern'd? 'tis I am the Cuckold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Slid Doctor, my Master sees us kissing, I am utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Feign your self in a sound, and I'l seem to rub you to fetch you to life again: Alak, help, help, who's within there, help. O, are you there, Sir? good Sir, run for a glass of cold water, I have much ado to keep life in her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I, with all my heart, and glad 'tis no worse.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Why the Devil must he fetch water? why could he not have sent me, I find I shall be the staple Cuckold for all the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: What a raskal art thou to fetch my Master?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: O you counterfeit quean, you are not in a sound then.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, you jealous rogue, but I'l counterfeit again as soon as my Master comes, and he shall believe it too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here he comes, fall into your sound again quick.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Here, here, alack poor Nurse, she does use to have fits.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I, a pox on her, more than e'er her mother had; Sir, give her no water, she counterfeits, she spoke as sensibly since you went as ever she did; deny it Doctor if you can.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What an uncharitable villain art thou to forge such a wicked lie? this rogue is made sure.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come you wicked knave, and help to lead her to her bed, you'l never leave your jealousie.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, she'l pull my ear off, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That's a sign of a strong fit, Sir, but lay her upon her bed, and she'l recover. Slid, Sir, I was never so surprised in my life; I was consulting with Nurse about your daughters health, and all o'th' sudden she fell into my arms in a sound: But now for your daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Dispatch and bring my Daughter hither with all care.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And good Sirs, bid my Apothecary come in.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What Apothecary is it, Sir? cannot you cure her without an Apothecary?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, Sir; you speak as if you were jealous.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Not jealous, Sir, but I love to know who comes in my house.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Neither Apothecary nor Doctor shall trouble you; so fare you well, and cure your daughter your self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay sweet Doctor, leave me not in this distress.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Be not jealous then.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Be not angry then. Hey ho, Doctor, my heart misgives me that my child will be stoln.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'l warrant you, whilst I am in your house. He smoaks us I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; is this your Apothecary?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What the reason may be, I know not, but my heart rises at him, though I never saw him before.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You make your life miserable with foolish phantasms: Pray, Sir, bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why you'r welcome, Sir; but to tell you truly, I like you not.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: If you please, I'l be gone, Sir. Do you think he has no hint of our design?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, no: Nay, Sir, if he go, I'l go with him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you both stay, for I doubt my child is dying. O here she comes, good Sir, look upon her.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Apothecary, feel her pulse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Is not that your office, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yet again? why, he is the most learned man in Europe, and to my shame I find, I cannot cure her without him; go, go, feel her pulse.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I fear my over joy will discover me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Mean time I'l tell you, Sir; 'tis a great question amongst we learned of Padua, whether men or women be hardest to cure; some are of one opinion, some another; mean time there be potent Arguments on either side.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: He is very long feeling her pulse methinks.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Pray you mind you me, Sir; first we hold, that women being naturally more cold than men, and cold being an enemy to life, it follows their cure must needs be more difficult and dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How many pulses has she to feel that he is thus long about it?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You do not mark me, Sir; I do not love to be slighted when I'm in argument.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I do mark you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Then I say 'tis generally held at Padua, that women, when they take physick, ought to have their potions much more stronger than men, because physick cannot work so well
upon cold and phlegmatick bodies, as upon hot and dry: You do not hear me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: They'r very close together methinks.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: A sign he minds his business: and this was the opinion of the great Cham of Tartar's chief Physician, that was fellow-student with me at Padua.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A pox of your great Cham, I must know why he dwells thus long upon her pulse; have you conveyed no Letters to her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What an uncivil question's that? Come Pothecary, let your Daughter die, and you perish; the world shall never make me visit her again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Dear Doctor, do not leave me in this extremity. Mr. Pothecary, will you be my overthrow too?

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I'l do no man service that affronts me thus.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen bear with an old mans passion: good Mr. Apothecary go to my child again.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: No, not I, Sir, I shall but convey Letters.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay then you'r cruel, I beseech your pardons Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well Sir, we see it is your weakness, and we pass it over; go to your Daughter whilst we consult a little: we must press to have her to your house to cure her.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Good, and if he refuses that, I'l perswade her to counterfeit madness; I have a design in't.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And that she may appear the more mad, let her tear all her cloaths off; for a mad woman naked has such antick temptations.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I should be loth any man should see her naked but my self, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, what have you concluded of?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, he must feel if he can discover of what side her heart lies: I'l keep him in discourse the mean while.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Must he feel her heart, Doctor? still it runs in my mind, this Apothecary will do me a mischief: nay, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Nay, I forgive you, I see an old man's twice a child,
pray you walk into the next room, I must talk in private with you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I should sound, if I should leave my child with the Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Let's talk here then, for look you, Sir.

div.stage: [They walk and seem to talk earnestly.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I'l observe all your directions; for if he will not let me go to your house, he shall find me mad enough, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: You see how jealous he is, therefore we have no other hopes of injoyment left but by this means.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I'll do my part, fear not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sure he feels something more than her heart all this while.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If there be occasion, we must stick at nothing.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Why, Sir, according to your opinion, I have found her heart on her right-side.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Most wonderful! pray you what may be the reason, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Love is certainly the cause on't, and for her cure, this is no place of convenience, therefore she must be removed to my house.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: To thy house thou wicked fellow? I told thee at my first sight of thee, I did not like thee.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: But there is all things ready that cannot be removed hither, Sir; my Tubs, my Baths, and my Sweating-house.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I like it not, it is a plot to steal my child, I doubt so: Nay, be not angry, Gentlemen, I do but doubt so.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You would make a man forswear doing you any service.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I crave your pardons once more; is there no art left to make her speak?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Yes, I could make her speak presently, but I doubt it will be but wildly, Sir, for love has shak'd her brain exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me have the comfort to hear her speak of any fashion, good Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: You shall, Sir; pray you Madam chaw that in your mouth: Sir, you shall see the effects of it straight: before you speak, put out your tongue, and wag it two or three times.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'l do any thing to purchase thee my dear Leander.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why does he imbrace her so? I do not like it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis something in order to her cure: I think you'r mad, Sir; you'l spoil all, he is but shaking her heart right.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I'm sure he shakes mine every time he touches her.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: A, a, a, a, a.

div.stage: [She rises up and stares, and wags her tongue.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O bless my child.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Be comforted, Sir, for now it works.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: A, a, a, a, a.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Is this your working? the Devil work, my child is undone.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay, now her tongue wags, she'l not be long ere she speak, fear not.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Who are all you, Sirs?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She speaks, she speaks, make me thankful to you for it, worthy Mr. Doctor and Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: What art thou? whence camest thou? and whither wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O me, I fear my child's distracted.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I told you, Sir, he sence was a little shaken.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Pray you, is not that the Devil in black, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, I'm but a Doctor yet Madam, I shall not take my degree of Devil this seven years.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Yet if you please Madam, he shall commence Devil presently.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Then good Doctor Devil, for you shall lose none of your titles here, Sir, help me to tear that beard of that old wrinkled weather-beaten tan'd old face.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am thy father, child.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I hope thou art not, I'd rather be a bastard than have thy ill nature in me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am thy old father, child.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I hate any thing that's old.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Wilt thou break thy old fathers heart?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Nay, that that's more precious to me than my father, which is my dear looking-glass, I would break that, if it were old; for sure the Devil invented old people on purpose to cross young lovers; they could ne'er have been so cruel else to poor Leander.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: My child is undone, she weeps for Leander.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Yes, and will weep again and again for Leander: Leander, Leander, Leander, why you do not love Leander; for which sin, good Doctor Divel take him into your Territories, and let him fall desperately in love with a young She-devil, and let that She-devil have a cross father, that will not let them come together, and then he'l feel the torment his poor child indures.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Doctor, this has too much sence and satyre in't to be madness.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O, Sir, 'tis madness to a high degree, and dangerous madness too.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: You look like Leander, Sir, you are so young and handsome, sure you are Leander.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I am so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, no, no Pothecary, do not say so I charge you what does he mean by holding up his finger so impudently?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: He makes signs to let you know he must say as she says to please her; for in Padua we deal with mad folks like those that catch Dottrils; when they stretch out a wing, we must stretch out an arm; if they stretch out a leg, you must do so too: else if we should cross her, she may fall into a raging fit, and tear us all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O most accursed madness!

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Why would you absent your self so long Leander? why lay you not your rosie cheek to mine, and throw your arms with sweet imbraces about your lover: I doubt you'r false Leander.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p:
Madam, may the earth open as I kneel, and make me
an example of falshood, if any unconstant thought be in me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why villain, Pothecary, talk no more so to her: why the Devil does he kneel? he speaks as feelingly, as if he were concern'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sir, there is no other way on earth to cure her but this.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The remedy is worse than the disease; come from her Pothecary, I told thee at first I did not like thee, I have a natural aversion against thee; confess, for I know thou art to do me a mischief: why were you so concern'd to kneel and make such protestations.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: By my life, Sir, I did it to please and to satisfie her, for she doubted I was false, and I swore I was not: alas, Sir, we must take these courses to recover her by saying as she says; for physick has the least hand in curing madness, I have cured twenty mad people this way.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you have a little satisfied me, and with reason too; but yet there is something within me that hates thee heartily.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Well, Sir, when I have cured your daughter, I hope you'l have a better opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I may of your Art, but never of you, I doubt; for thy conscience knows thou art to cozen me; nay, do not tell the Doctor so.

div.stage: [He offers to go to the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Troth Lady, you are so fine a mad woman, that 'tis a thousand pities you should e'er come to your self again; faith for a frolick take me by th' ears, and lead me round the room.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: If you will have it so Doctor, but I shall make you repent it: I have him, I have him; and now I'l tear him all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O save the Doctor, save the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Sweet Lady spare the Doctor, I'm your friend Leander, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I will do any thing for Leander; but you must stay and live with me then.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: You see, Sir, how very calm the very name Leander has made her: troth, Sir, I doubt you must be forc'd to send for Leander.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I doubt we cannot cure her without him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She shall die mad first, and I'll die with her; this is a plot, carry my child to her chamber; get out of my house you Villains.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You shall lay your hands under our feet before we come under your unworthy roof again.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Let me go with Leander, Leander, Leander.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You have made a fine hand to make my Mistress thus mad; I'l weary you out of your life for this.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You are very bold with your Master, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: There's an English Proverb says, If you lie with your Maid, she'll take a stool and sit down by her Master.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, well, I say again, she shall never marry but the Squire.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: She shall never marry your fool Softhead,
She shall first marchandise her Maiden-head.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: NO dear cousin, I was not dumb, nor am I mad, I have trusted you with my love, and in that my life.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Dear Cousin, doubt me not; when I am false to you, may I miscarry in my own Amours: but pray you Couz, how came you by this lover Leander? for none o'th' house knows him.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Truly Couz I never saw him but at Church.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: A very good place to make love in.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Indeed, I have found it so, the first time I saw him was six Pews from me, the next time he sate within two, and there he warm'd my heart: the next after he sate i'th' same Pew with me; and 'twas so ordered betwixt him and the Pew-keeper, that none sate with us, and there we loved, and there we plighted troth.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: I find a Pew-keeper is a worthy friend to love, and for sixpence you may sit with whom you please, and court whom you please i'th' Church: It was handsomely contrived of your Lover though, to come with the Doctor as his Apothecary; but what made him perswade you to counterfeit madness?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: He has a design in't but had not time to tell me; my father has turn'd the Doctor off you see, therefore Couz you must go to him.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: He'l find some stratagem to see you again, fear not; if not, I'l go to him: but come Couz, now lets laugh at the Duel, that the Squires foot-boy told us of his Master.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I, he found if safer killing of a sheep than Leander.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: No doubt on't: your father's bringing of him in to woo you again; fall to your madness, and let me alone to dispose of the Squire; I'l have him drawn up with an Engine, and there he shall hang i'th' Air in a Cardle till you'r married, or run away: Here they come, let us withdraw a little.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But how came your face thus black and blew, and thus black patch'd? I never saw a Ladies face thus furnished.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: They may be thus furnish'd when they please; but they shall never come so honourably by their black patches as I have done.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray you how came you by them?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Do you take these for patches? O dull old age! these are badges, badges of honour: look you my sword is glazed with honour too; but you shall ne'er know how, it has sost me two hundred pounds already confessing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I know it already, Sir; but Squire, I fear you did not court my Daughter handsomely; what said you when you wooed her?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I wooed her with all the fashionable questions of the Town; I askt her if she could come a seven, and she laught at me; then I askt her if she would come the caster, and I'd cover her: no man could say fairer to his Mistriss I think; then I askt her if she could drink Burgundy, and seal Bonds, pay the price of a Chine of Beef, for a dish of French Trotters; and that's all I said to her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I would thou hadst more wit, or I thy precious Acr • s. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Bid them bring in my Daughter, if she be awake: I hope she may take you for Leander; for she is now out of her dumbness, and is faln stark mad.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: How, can she speak? and is she mad? Heart of a horse, I'l be mad with her for a hundred pound: O I do so love to be mad; and will she be drunk too?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Drunk you bruit you? no.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why, how can she be mad then? I cannot be mad till I'm drunk, for my life; but I'l try what I can do.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But be sure you humour her, and say every thing as she says.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Let me alone, here she comes: Slid how delicately she stares.

div.stage: Enter Olinda, Nib. Nurse and Servants.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: What's that with the pye-bauld face? how camest thou so distracted, thou errand Knight?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: For thy sweet sake, thou divelish damsel.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Thou art as mad as I am.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: I am stark mad, for my mother was born in March: therefore let us be married.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I would not be so mad for all the world.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: And when we are married, we'l out-do the Great Mogul for new fashions; instead of six Flaunders Mares, our Coach shall be drawn with six Centaures.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Centaures! in the name of madness what are them?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: A Centaure is a horse born with a Postilian on's back.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: And shall all the Foot-men ride behind the Coach?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Yes, o'th' backs of one another, like March Frogs in a Ditch; and there they shall spawn young Foot-boys.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: And at the Boot of your Coach must be running an Orang-wench, presenting your Lady a sweet Lemmon with a love-Letter in't.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Right, and instead of Points and guilded Nails, our Coach shall be trim'd round with Cartridges.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: And they shall be fill'd with Powder and Shot to defend us.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: No, each Cartridge shall have a little tine Page in it, with his head peeping out like Hictius doctius.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Bi'rlady, I think they are both mad.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: What wonders would I do for my true love.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: There is a verse of a Song to that purpose, I'l sing it: What wouldst thou do for thy true love, if she for help should call?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Why, I would fight with a great Gyant, though he were ne'er so tall.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Thou fight with a Gyant? he must be in sheep-skin then.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Heart of a horse, how came she by that?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Go bid my Conjurer come.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Here, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Let me see Elisium quickly, and tell me truly what they do there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Madam, it is so little, and so like what's done in this world, that it is not worth your knowing; but since you command I must obey; let idle Poets speak their fancies of Elisium, but I that have been there must speak the truth; in short, Madam, all the women do nothing but sing, John come kiss me now; and then the men give 'em a green Gown upon the flowry banks, and there they commit love together.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Do they not dance in Elisium?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes Madam, as you shall see; every one keep their stand. Squire, stand you here.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Must I see the Devil?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Would I were devilish drunk then.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Why would you be drunk, Squire?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Because they say when I'm drunk the Devil would not keep me company.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You must know my Devil scorns to be commanded with canting mountebank words, he is a Sea-faring kind of Divel, that comes when his boson whistles; stand fast.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Save the Squire, Save the Squire.

div.stage: He whistles, Elisium opens, many womens voices sing, John come kiss me now, after that a dance; they draw up Squire Softhead with a Divel, and he cryes out.
Enter Jarvis, and Isabel, Nurse unseen.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Tell my Master all the lies you can invent of him; for I know women are good at sudden invention.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Yes, I Could lie sufficiently to do his work; that is, I can lie my part, if you can swear yours.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: If you do not second your lying with swearing, we shall do no good on't.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Nay, by my troth if I lie, I expect you should swear to it; 'tis your revenge as well as mine, and you shall bear your part.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Troth, I am not very good at swearing.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Then do you lie, and I'l swear; take your choice, for 'tis all one to me.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Nay, we must second one another both with swearing and lying, as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: That I had but some witnes of this Villany.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'l warrant you, we'l spoil his being a Doctor, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You shall not, if I can help it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'l tell your Master first, he is a drunken Farrier, and no Doctor, a villain not to own his wife.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: How, is this his wife? I dare say 'tis for my sweet sake he does not own her: poor dear Doctor!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I'l be reveng'd to the full.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: So will I till I am full.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I'll give you my wives new Gown, and take your revenge my way.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O rogue, a Cuckold to the ninth degree.

sp.speaker: Isa.
Jar.
sp.p: But first, let us consider, and lay our story ready.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I'l to the Doctor and tell him all this: what a slave is this husband of mine? O rogue that cannot be content to be a Cuckold, but he must be a whore-master too; thou shalt have more than an ordinary head, for that at Amboes shall appear but a Pricket to thee, for thou shalt be a monstrous. Cuckold, if man or beast can make thee one.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I doubt Doctor we shall never win the old mans favour again.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Troth, I think you were never in't, for his bloud rose at the very first sight of you.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: He finds by instinct the mischief I'm to do him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, 'tis now come in my head to gain his opinion again.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: O my dear Doctor, how!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why thus; you shall write a Love-Letter to your Mistriss, as you are Leander, and then deliver it to th' old man, as you'r my Apothecary, I'l go with you too.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: What advantage will that be?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: We'l tell him, that Leander hearing that we gave his Mistriss physick, offer'd us a lusty sum to convey a Letter to her; and finding how heartily he resolves against Leander, we thought fit to shew our selves honest by delivering him the Letter.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: In troth this may clear the jealousie he had of us, and bring us in again.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Apot.
sp.p: It would argue very little wit indeed; but come let us about the Letter. Slid, here comes Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O, Mr. Doctor, I must tell you, you'r a man of little conscience to make such true love to me, as you have done, and have a wife as you have.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Truly Nurse I had thought you had had more honesty than to suffer me to make such love to you, and have a husband as you have.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: But Doctor I came to tell you, that the woman that my Cuckold makes love to, swears she is your wife, and says you'r no Doctor, but a Farrier, and a drunkard, and a beggar, and they'r just now going to my Master to tell him so; nay, they'r resolved to lie and swear all things they can invent against you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: There is no great invention in so much truth: a pox on 'em, what shall we do? all our designs are quite spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I am undone to all eternity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'tis I am undone, for I must turn Farrier again; Nurse I'l come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I'm utterly destroy'd, if I get not off o'this.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I have it already, run you to Bedlam, and give two of the whippers a piece, and bring them hither, and tell them they own my wife for a mad woman, and carry her to Bedlam, and force her with all violence, and keep her there till further orders.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I'l instruct them farther, as they come along.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Do so, make haste, and flie like Gun-shot. Now Nurse, this was kindly done indeed to tell me this Nurse; but be not troubled, for she is not my wife, but a mad woman broke out of Bedlam; and now I am resolved to marry thee Nurse, for I see thou lovest me truly.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, but Doctor, you know I've a Husband.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Hang him, I were a pitiful Doctor to suffer any body to live that I have occasion to have dead.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: If it could be done with a safe conscience.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, if it be safely done, it's done with a safe conscience; I see thou'rt a fool and knows nothing.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You Learned men know best, I leave all to you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou shalt lead the sweetest live Nurse; first I will get my son and heir my self Nurse, and then thou shalt have a brave gallant with a fine white Periwig that cost twenty pound Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O dear Doctor, how sweetly you express your love to me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And then your gallant shall carry you abroad, and bring you home o' nights: so well pleas'd, Nurse!

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O my most obliging Doctor!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And then thou shalt throw that gallant off, Nurse, and have one with a brave brown Periwig, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Did ever man shew such true love to a woman? let all husbands take example by this dear Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And then thou shalt have one with a brave black Periwig, Nurse, so that thou shalt have Children of all colours i'th' Rain-bow: but why dost thou weep, Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I weep for joy to think what a comfortable life I shall lead with you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And dare you be true to your young Mistriss and Leander, and help to bring them together, Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I deserve to starve for a true lover else.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But then you must be true to your Master, and tell him when they'r together; and then you oblige both parties, you know.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: By my troth, and so I shall; and I'l be sure to follow your directions.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I dare swear thou wouldst: but Nurse, I do but jest, I would not wrong the old Gentleman for the whole earth.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Nor I for all the world.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But Nurse, go tell your Master that the woman is a mad woman of Bedlam; you may swear you have seen her there, for 'tis very true, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I will do it truly Doctor; but when shall our happy day of marriage be, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: As soon as you can perswade your husband to take physick.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Let me alone for that. O dear Doctor, this fine white Periwig does so run in my head.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And does not the brown one do so too?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Yes, by my troth, and the black one eke also.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I dare not trust this Jade for all this; yet for little things, which may be helps to the main, I shall venture to try her in.

div.stage: Enter Apothecary, and two Officers of Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Mr. Doctor, I have brought you a couple of Officers for your turn, they both understand, and are ready to serve you for your money.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But have you given them instructions?

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: O, Sir, we have it throghly.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You must be confident, for you'l find a damn'd scould of her.

sp.speaker: 2 Offi.
sp.p: O, Sir, we that can tame mad folks, can tame a scould, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: And though the woman be not mad, we can make her mad, if you please.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Prethee how?

sp.speaker: 2 Offi.
sp.p: With these Engines: why people are not so mad when they come to Bedlam, as they are when they'r in't, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: How comes that I prethee?

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p:
Do you think that the food of bread and water, to lie naked in foul straw, and to be whipt twice a day, will
〈◊〉 make any body mad? I'l warrant you faith.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But do you give them no physick?

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
Doct.
sp.p: That plainly shews the circulation of the bloud; and this may be cited a consultation.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you see they know their work, therefore about it, and there is more money to incourage you.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: You shall hear of her in Bedlam, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Now let's about our Letter with all speed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come on, and if all fail, we'l fetch your Mistriss to Bedlam; for she is pretty well entred into madness already.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: No, then people will say, If she had not been mad, she'd ne'er been in love with me; yet any where out of her fathers house does it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, if our other designs fail, faith have at that.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Thou wretched old man, first to make thy Daughter mad, and then to keep her in't with thy cruelty, when your own conscience knows a husband would recover her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But now my mind is altered; for I'm resolved, let her perish, she shall never marry whilst I live.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: At your peril be it, for I'l take my oath before a Judge that a husband would bring her to her wits again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I renounce and disclaim her.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: A husband I tell you: Second me Nurse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I'm resolved I'l hear of no husband.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I tell you once again a husband.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: And I tell you moreover and above a husband.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: And I tell you both under and over, and over and under a husband.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: A husband, a husband, a husband.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I'l stop my ears, I'l hear no more of her.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: But in troth Uncle, consider soberly her sad condition, she is young, and her bloud gallops in her veins, and requires the satisfaction of a Gentleman, I prescribe her nothing but what I would take my self.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Alack she might take it if she were a dying.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Cannot the comforts of a Father recover her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Nor of a mother neither, if her heart be set the other way.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then let her dye mad, for I'l hear of no such thing as husband.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: With all my heart, I wish she would marry thy Gardiner.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, that she might taste of his Apricocks: Nay, nay, nay, you shall hear us out, for look you Master, a husband is such a thing.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: I truly Uncle, a husband is such a thing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What a thing is a husband?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Why, a thing a young woman cannot be without.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, nor an old woman neither.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: A husband is a thing that's good for many things.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: A husband is good to father his wives children.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Pray you let him be good at getting them first.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No matter, that's a thing may be done without him; I see you are a young woman and know nothing.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Then a husband is a thing that is a good Cloak for a womans knavery.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, if a husband could be brought to do the civil office of an orang-woman, to fetch and carry, he were worth his weight in gold; I have a husband, my Master knows, is the untowardest peevish fellow at it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Away, away, you idle woman.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: You mean down right pimping, Nurse, that's a little against the hair methinks for a husband. Ben. Johnson says, fathers and mothers make the best bauds.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Bauds! your Johnson's an ill bred foul-mouth'd fellow to call them so; besides he is a fool, for a husband's worth a hundred fathers and mothers for that office; for then the wife's unstain'd, the world cannot taint her, when the husband gives her countenance.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: But will you consider your daughters madness?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, he has turn'd off a worthy Doctor, and his Apothecary that would have cured her, and now he's jealous of 'em, and will not let 'em come near her.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: 'Slife, I'l indite you for murther, I'l not see my Cousin cast away thus: send for this Doctor, I say.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Here is a woman, if it please you, has something to say to you concerning the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I, what is it woman?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I would be loth to have your worship abused; this Doctor, if it please you, that comes to your house is a very raskal: swear to it now.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I by my feckars-law is he.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Swear up roundly and be hang'd; is feckars-law an oath to pass before a Judge? I say this Doctor is a raskal.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, he may be ne'er the worse Doctor for that.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But he is not a Doctor, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, he may be ne'er the worse raskal for that.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: But as I said, he is no Doctor, but a down right Farrier.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A Farrier, bi'rlady a good foundation to raise a Doctor upon; I like him ne'er the worse.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Besides he is a beggar, and I am his wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: If thou be'st his wife, 'tis an even lay but he's a beggar.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Besides we have had five children, and now he will not own me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: That confirms him a good Doctor still, I say,

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: This woman is mad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She talks sensibly enough, and I believe her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am not mad, Sir, and I tell you he is but a Farrier. Swear and be hang'd, you leave me sweetly i'th' lurch. I say he can give your daughter a drench, and shooe her before and behind, and that's all he knows of a Doctor.

sp.speaker: 2 Offi.
sp.p: By your leave we must make bold with your worship; we have a mad woman broak out of Bedlam, and we understand she is come into your worships house. O are you there you mad quean, must we have all this labour to find you with a pox? I'l scourge you to some purpose i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What dost thou mean fellow? this is my servant.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You rogue, you villain, you raskal.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: Sir, pray you pardon him, this fellow is a stranger, and come newly to his office, since she stole out of Bedlam; this is the quean, Sir, she knows me well enough; look, look, look, if it please your worship, how the mad whore stares at me, now she sees me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I mad? I in Bedlam, you rogue? 'tis that thing, that Gentlewoman thing that looks like a mad woman.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: 'Slight, I'l away and secure my Cousin.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I hope they do not come for my daughter, Nurse.

sp.speaker: 1 Offi.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, come you quean, away with her: Why, Sir, we have had this wretch in Bedlam this dozen years; and sometimes she is so well, that we let her go about the house, and then she steals out, and 'tis sometimes a week before we can find her again. Fare you well, Sir; Slid how I'l lash the whore.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: This woman being mad, confirms me the Doctor is wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: The woman is his wife, and not mad, Sir; and the fellow is no Doctor, but a Farrier, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: The rogue is jealous of the Doctor, and that makes him say so, as he is of your worship, when I rise a nights to rub your shins.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I say again, he is a Farrier and no Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
This must be scandal, for I believe he is a learned
man. How now? what do you here, Sir? did not I forbid you my house? Are you a Farrier, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Are you a changeling, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why changeling, fellow?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why Farrier, fool?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: He is wrong'd sure by his angry confidence.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Who told you I was a Farrier, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A woman that said she was your wife, and truely I believed it, till two Officers of Bedlam fetcht her away, and said she was a mad woman.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Alack, alack, was it she; why that poor creature has been in Bedlam this many years; and she has call'd me husband so long, that of my conscience the poor wretch believes it to be so indeed.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I, but Mr. Doctor, my husband swears you'r a Farrier.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Who, that villain? why thou scandalous rogue, how darst thou wrong me, when thou hast discovered such strange things to me of thy Master?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I, what has the rogue discover'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: First, he is damnable jealous of you; next he told me that you got his wives child, and he desir'd us of all loves to give you some cantharides to disable you for getting of children: ask my Apothecary else.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Sir, they wrong me, and they lye.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: But they do not swear and lie, as thou and the mad woman did: Sir, I'l swear upon a book I over-heard them make the bargain, she was to lie, and he was to swear to it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Pothecary, you over-heard that too, did you not?

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I did so, Sir, and I'l be deposed upon't: you put me to hard duty Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You villain out of my house.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Sir, they do me wrong, I never said so.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I know you were always a jealous raskal, and therefore must believe 'em; so get you out you villain.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Sirrah, will you be content to be a Cuckold yet?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I'l be reveng'd, for I'l cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'l be even with thee, for I'l give thee physick.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pay him his wages, and let him be gone.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Give me my wife then.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, I mean to physick her, and make her fit for a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I'l have my wife, if there be law.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Thou shalt have her before thy suit is ended; for by that time every body will have done with her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Come, sir, I'l pay you your wages, you see what comes of jealousie; could not you be content to hear, and see, and say nothing?

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: But, Sir, our business is to present you with this Letter, and withal to advise you to look strictly to your daughter; for this Leander is contriving several stratagems to steal her, he offer'd us I know not what to deliver her this Letter.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But we knowing it would break your heart, we thought our selves bound in conscience to bring you the Letter, and withal to advise you to be careful of your child, for to my knowledge she'l be gone else; so having fairly discharged our selves, we take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O do not go, you are my friends, you have proved your selves my faithful friends; I beseech you stay and take care once more of my child.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Not for the world, Sir, we came not to that end, Sir, we came to shew our selves honest men, and that being now clear'd, our credits shall come no more in question.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I beseech you leave me not.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, your passion will spoil all our practice; for should it be noys'd abroad, that a Doctor of physick carries letters betwixt party and party, 'twere enough to undo us all.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen, I have received comfort by your fidelity, take it not from me again by your obstinacie; I once more beseech you to take the care of my child upon you.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: Alack, Sir, do not weep, we'l do any thing to serve you, but our credits are so precious to us.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good men, I'l never distrust you more, you have shew'd such worth in the discovery of this Letter, that I weep for joy to think I have found such faithful friends.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: In troth my tender Nature melts too, see, see, my poor Apothecary weeps too.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Dost thou cry too, Nurse? alack poor woman.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: How can I chuse but cry, to see my Master weep?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I thought you had cryed to part with your husband, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Your own conscience knows I do not love him so well: Pray you good Master wipe your eyes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good Doctor and Apothecary weep no more.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: We cannot hold to see your grief so great, Sir.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah, ah, ah, ah:

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Let us cry in four parts, and see how 'twill go.

sp.speaker: Apot.
sp.p: I have heard of singing in four parts, but never of crying in four parts before: come, Sir, take comfort, for once more we will undertake your child.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: We must first repair home, to provide things fit for her, and then without delay we come: once more we have fastned of him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen make haste: Come hither, Nurse, this was kindly done to weep, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I could not chuse but weep to see you weep.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: In the middle of my sorrows, there is some comfort in thee yet; come kiss me, Nurse, I hope thou hast been true to me, Nurse, and not suffer'd that raskal thy husband to come near thee.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Do you think I'd be so false a wretch, as to let my husband touch me? I wish the heavy judgement of such a sin may fall on me, if ever he so much as kist me, or ever shall whilst your worship lives; for sure you have been a sweet man in your youth, that is such a comfort to a woman in your old age.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But am I such a comfort to thee indeed, Nurse? do not dissemble with me.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
If I do, I wish I may never enter into the—why
am I a woman? but why do you suspect me so?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Because I thought the Doctor had kist you, when you were in's arms.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: That you should think such a wicked thing of me, when you saw I'd a fit of the mother.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Weep not Nurse, I am satisfied, come kiss and be friends.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Look, look of that old sinckanter, here's a fine mouldy gallant, an old grey badger; I must play the rogue with him, though I suffer for it.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Slid your Niece sees you kiss me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Alack, I am asham'd for ever then: good Nurse sound as you did when the Doctor rub'd you.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Do you think I can counterfeit sounding? besides do you think you are able to rub me as the Doctor did?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: O wo is me, and wo unto us all, O this Uncle, this wicked Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Alack, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: O cruel destiny! O fatal fortune!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, Niece Nibby, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: That ever I should live to see this day.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O my dear Mrs. Nibby, what's the misfortune?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: O where should I find this cursed Uncle of mine?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Here I am Nibby, what's the danger?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: You are undone and ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How, undone and ruin'd? do not delay me.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: O your daughter, your daughter you wicked wretch, I am not able to say more for grief.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ah, oh, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Tell me quickly what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Why, your daughter's grown desperate mad at your unkindness; ran to the window that stands over the River, and there opening the great casement.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O what did she then?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p:
Why, lifting up her hands and eyes to that good place, where you will never come Uncle; she loudly cryed, Since
my father has abandon'd me, 'tis time for me to quit this life of mine.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And so threw her self into the River?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: No, it seems she did not like that kind of death.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why, what then?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Why then she ran like lightning to the Table, where your Pocket-Pistol lay.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And so shot her self with that?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: No, it seems there was no powder i'th' pan, but bitterly sighing and weeping, at last she ran and desperately threw her self upon her bed, and then growing paler and paler, by degrees fell into a deadly sound.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And so dyed?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Stay, stay, you'r too quick for your daughter; but with much rubbing, tumbling and tossing her, I brought her to life again; so leaving her at deaths door, I came to tell you the news.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Where are my servants? run, bid 'em run, I'l have a consultation of Doctors; and run for Doctor Drench, for he shall joyn in councel with 'em.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I'l to the Doctor and tell him this. I doubt he will not like a consultation with Physicians.
sp.l: If he stand this brush, he's made for ever;
Luck if't be thy will just now or never.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE 1.
div.stage: Enter Doctor, Leander and Parson Othentick.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: LOok you Doctor, this Gentleman is my brother; and, though he be young, a Minister in orders; I have told him what we design'd, and he is to go as my Apprentice, and carry our feigned physick.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Very good, and can you step out of a Pulpit into an Apothecaries Shop? poyson a friend or two, and steal to your Text again without scruple of conscience?

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Sir, I shall go as near the wind as a Dutch Skiper, to serve my brother, but I hope there is no poyson in the case.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, but there is a little cheat.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Which I hope you may dispence with.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Truly I hope I may to serve my brother.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Or your Sister.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Yes sure, to serve any of my Relations.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Or a friend.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: So it be a dear friend.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Or a stranger with a good living to present.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: That's a good thing still.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: The Doctor's merry, brother: but pray you let me help you off with your Reverend Weeds, and appear like an Apothecary's Apprentice, or a Disciple of Paracelsus.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Now Doctor give me leave to be merry with you, I studyed physick, and should have profest it, and an old Doctor gave me some rules for a young Doctor to observe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Pray you let's hear them by all means.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p:
First, have always a grave busie face, as if you were
still in great care for some great persons health, though your meditations truly known are only imployed in casting where to eat that day: Secondly, be sure you keep the Church strictly on Sundays; and i'th' middle o'th' Sermon, let your man fetch you out in great haste, as if 'twere to a Patient; then have your small Agent to hire forty Porters a day to leave impertinent notes at your house, and let them knock as if 'twere upon life and death; these things the world takes notice of, and you'r cryed up for a man of great practice, and there's your business done.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Believe me these are good instructions.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Nay, I have more, be sure you ingratiate your self with the Bauds, pretending to cure the poor Whores for charity, that brings good private work after it. Strike in with Mid-wives too, that you may be in the councel for by-blows, that secures a Patient during life; and with Apothecaries, and Nurse-keepers go snips; but above all acquire great impudence, lest you be out of countenance at your own miscarriages.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am so well stockt with that, that if ever impudence come to be worship'd as a Deity, they'l set me upon a pedestal for their god.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But to our business Doctor, you know we perswaded the old man that we must say and do all things to humour his seeming mad daughter, and by that only way she is to be recover'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Right, and the old man believes it too.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Therefore when we are there, you shall hold the father in discourse whilst I whisper her; and as she and I will manage her madness, my Brother shall marry us to the old mans face.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Lea.
sp.p: Therefore pack up your pretended physick, and let us chearfully about it.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Save you Gentlemen, you are much long'd for, my old Master does so talk of the Doctor, and my young mad Mistress of the Pothecary, that you must come with all speed; for my Mistress is so stark mad, that my Master has sent for three or four learned Doctors; and you must make haste, and bring all your Learning with you; for you must sit in consultation with them.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: In consultation with Doctors? 'heart all is spoil'd again, and worse than ever 'twas. Tell your Master plainly, Nurse, consultation with Doctors is not my way of practice; a company of wrangling fellows, they can never agree; besides, he under-values me to think I am not able to cure her without help: but Nurse, go into my chamber, and turn over St. Aratines book, till I talk with my Pothecary.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: With all my heart, dear Doctor.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This is the unfortunatest cross that e'er befel me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The Divel hath conspired against you: so farewel for an unluckie wretch, I'l put on my Apron, and profess Farrier again; and then let the Doctors and the Divel come, I defie them.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Nay, nay, stay Doctor and let us consider.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Consider? do you think I can support an Argument with able Physicians?

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Come, be not dismaid, for we will go, if there were a whole College of Physicians; I am a Scholar, and a proficient in physick, and those questions that you cannot answer, put them upon me, and doubt not but we will baffle them all; therefore we must be wary, and not talk too much of Padua, for ten to one but some of 'em has been there, and they are strict Galenists, therefore we must be Chymists: Now you must not call my brother your Apothecary, nor me his Apprentice, that will not sound like an out-landish Physician, therefore call him Hurnatio your Operator, and me Stirquilutio his man.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well boys, you have so incouraged me, that I have just now a trick come into my head to baffle them all my self.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: O brave Doctor! what is't? what is't?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You shall know, but Nurse must be in the plot.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: By no means i'th' earth, she'l betray us all.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Lea.
sp.p: That may go a great way; but

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But me no buts; Nurse, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Here my dear Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nurse, tell your Master that I am resolved to consuit with the Doctors; but 'tis for thy sweet sake I'l swear, Nurse: therefore my dear Nurse, if thou lovest mirth, and will be true to me, we'l put such a trick upon these learned Physicians, that we'l laugh seven years after it.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Here's my hand and heart, dear Doctor, I'l be true to you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I believe thee; be sure Nurse, that you be in the room; and when I bid you fetch your Mistresses water, be sure you go out and bring me your own; and then mark what work I'l make with your learned Doctors.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Why, this will please me above all things, most hugely, most strangely.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I, but if Nurse should cozen you, and neither bring her Mistresses water nor her own, she would serve you finely.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I scorn to be so base, Sir, and if you think so, Sir, you may be by when 'tis made, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct
sp.p: Nay, be not angry Nurse, for my Apothecary, my Operator I should say, is to give your husband physick when he is to die, and he knows I'm to marry you, I've told him all; nay, he is as true as steel.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Is he so, Sir? I crave your pardon for my hasty speech:
the Doctor reports you'r as true as steel, Sir; and I assure you I honour any Gentleman that has either truth or steel in him▪ I shall inform my Master of your coming; and I assure you, Sir, you shall command my water without fraud or guile.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Let us now consider how to answer these learned Doctors▪

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: That cannot be, for we know not what they will fall upon.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I find I shall betray my self to be a damn'd Farrier; but however I'l brazen it out.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: Doctor, you must be sure you consent not to consult in private, which they will desire, because they never agree; besides, urge that the Father, Nurse, and we may be admitted, it will be a good excuse for your worship not to speak Latin.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But by the way, you must furnish me with a snip or two of Latin to save my credit.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.p: That's easily done, but you must be sure to imbroil the Doctors first with some strange questions, to prevent their falling upon you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'l do it,
sp.l: And spite of all their Scruples, Drams and Ounces,
I will confound these learned Doctor Dounces.

div.stage: Enter old Gernette with three learned Doctors.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I have made bold to send for you again, and though you could not help my child when she was dumb, I hope you may now she is mad.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: How, is she mad? and does she speak?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, a famous and a learned man, of great skill, and wonderful knowledge, gave her something, and in a short time she spake, and fell into raving fits of madness, and has ever since continued so; and this he told me would be the effect of what he then did.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Most wonderful! what was it he gave her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, that I know not, but I assure you, he said he could make her speak, and told me her disease would turn to madness, and accordingly it has proved so; nevertheless, Gentlemen, I desire you to joyn with this Learned man, and consider how to perfect her cure.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you tell us wonders of him; where did he study?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I know not, but he seems to be a great Traveller, for he talkt of Tartar Cham, and of Padua, and Greenland.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Tartar Cham and Green-land? this must be a Mountebank and a cheat.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Upon my credit you will not find him so, for he has seen all Universities, he is but newly come over, and his name is Doctor Drench.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: Drench? why that's a fitter name for a Farrier than a Physician.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let his name be as strange as it will, he has also strange humours too, for he'l find out mens ignorance presently.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: I think we were best be gone, lest he finds out ours.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: Why I, for if he be a Chymist, his opinion and ours must needs differ, and consequently not agree in consultation.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I am, Sir, of your opinion, for I think it infradignitatem to hold consultation with Mountebanks.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: We know not yet, Sir, what the man is.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: If he be a Chymist, Sir, he is eo nomine, a declared enemy to the Galenical way, to all truth and learning, and a denyer of principles; and therefore not to be consulted with.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
3 Doct.
sp.p:
Pardon me Gentlemen, I have known some Chymical Physicians learned and rational men; and although not strict adherers to the Galenical Method, proceed with great
reason, and good success, which, I take it, answers all we can say or do.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I profess I think it as bad as murder to cure out of the methodical way. Oh what satisfaction 'tis to have a patient dye according to all the Rules of Art.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But sure it should satisfie your conscience better to have them live by Rules.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Come life, come death, to follow Rules is your satisfaction, and Conscience is no ingredient within the Rules of Physick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the Doctor is come.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis well: Gentlemen, to end this dispute here is a double fee for each, and pray you consult with him his way, and be civil in't for my sake.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: Sir, you and yours here hath prevailed over us.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I profess to serve so worthy and magnificent a person, I would consult with a Farrier.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: A Farrier? nay, for a double fee, we would consult with a Gun-smith.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Here he is, pray you salute him.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: We know how to be civil, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Doctor Hurnatio and Stirquilutio, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Save you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: One save you, Sir, is sufficient for all, we Learned men should hate complement, Verba panca sapiens sapit: was that true Latin, Parson?

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: Brave! fear nothing: at them with some question.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I shall fall into the Farrier. Well, I find, Gentlemen, you are professed Doctors of Physick, and are met to consult the health of a distracted Ladie; therefore to the point, and avoid your canting words, that would stick in a wise mans throat and choak him.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p:
But, Sir, 'tis necessary we deliver our selves in proper and learned phrases, when we discourse either of Physick
or Distempers, In Arte artificialiter loquendum; and withal, Sir, 'tis fit that we of the consultation should withdraw.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No withdrawing, Sir, 'tis not my way, I love persons concern'd should hear and see what's done, that they may judge who are doers, and who are talkers; and if you affect the vain-glory of learned phrases, my Operator Hurnatio, and his man Stirquilutio shall dispute you; for with great pains I have inabled them to argue in all tongues, because they know I hate the trouble on't my self.

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: Start a question quickly.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I shall only trouble you with one question or two my self: First, I ask you whether you know the practice of before behind, behind before?

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Before behind, behind before? why, that is something belongs to a horse, a Farrier or a Blacksmith must answer that question.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I know where you'd be presently, in some sort 'tis true that you say; yet in Italy both woman and boys have their before behind, behind before, as well as your horses have here.

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: Bravely come off Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I know not well your way of practice, but the cost you put the people to in that common disease, call'd the mourning of the Chine, I do abominate you for.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Mourning of the Chine? with your favour, Sir, that is the disease of a Horse, and the phrase of a Farrier.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And, Sir, I say again, I call it the mourning of the Chine, for the word Pox is a phrase of ill manners; and therefore I think it proper to call it the Pox in a Horse, and civil to call it the mourning of the Chine in a man.

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: You'l have no need of Latin, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Look you to that Parson: and I must tell you I shall spoil the benefit you get by that disease; for I'l advise every man to plant a Guaicum-Tree in his Orchard, and a Leaf of that at any time will cure infallibly, and that's one of the secrets I will reveal to the world, to spoil the practice of Mountebanks, clap Doctors and bill men.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: But will that disease be cured with the Leaf of a Guaicum-tree?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I, Sir, as I can order it.

sp.speaker: 1 Doct.
sp.p: Pray you, Sir, how will you order it?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why first, Sir, I will make you a mash.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: How, Sir, that's a Farriers phrase again, what mean you by a mash, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Tell 'em, tell 'em Stirquilutio, and let not me be troubled to interpret.

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: Why, Sir, the Doctor is so much read in the Arabian Physicians, that he often uses their terms: Masha in the Arabick is what quinta essentia is in the Latin.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well helpt Parson: you wonder at my phrases, and I at your want of Arabick. Now, Sir, when any man is troubled with the staggers, we do not cut him and slash him in the forehead as you do your Horses.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Staggers in a man? with your favour, Sir, you have talkt all this while liker a Farrier than a Physician; and I begin to think you are one, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: How shall I get off now?

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he is a Farrier, and an able Farrier too; for if you be not good Farriers, and good Surgeons too, you deserve not the name of Doctors.

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: And pray you come to the point concerning our mad patient.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I, there's the best tryal of our judgements, therefore Nurse, run and fetch your young Mistresses water presently.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I, that the Gentlemen may the better judge what to apply, and I beseech you Gentlemen agree, that I and my child may find comfort from you.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Sir, you shall be sure of all the aid our Art can shew.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And likewise our endeavours, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: But, Sir, amongst all signs of sickness or health, whereby the skilful Physician is led into the knowledge of the state of the body; two above the rest are most certain, which are the Pulse and Urin.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: I, whereof the Pulse shews the state of the Heart and Arteries, and Urin the state of the Liver and Veins.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Therefore the question is, whether of these two severally consider'd, does give the most certain signification.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Stir.
sp.p: Then I say, Montanus de excrementis says.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I say, give them reasons in their own mother tongue.

sp.speaker: Stir.
sp.p: Then I say, the Urin above the Pulse, gives the most manifest, certain, and general signification of all diseases, because with the bloud it is conveyed into all parts of the body; and from thence returns back again in the Veins, to the Liver and Vessels of Urin, and so brings is some note of the state and disposition of all those parts from whence it comes.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis wonderful that an under-servant to a Doctor should have this learning.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I doubt whether the Master understand so much.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir, I'l be even with you: Parson, I'l tell that Doctor he is not well, and whilst I feel his Pulse, convey you this Cow-itch down his neck. Come hither, Sir, I pray you.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Your pleasure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You are not well, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: As ever I was in my life, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Let me feel your Pulse: you accuse me of Farriers phrases, I've another Farrier phrase for you; you are not well, you are founder'd in your body, and it will fall upon your shoulders: first, it will begin with a kind of itching, then into Inflammations and Catarrhs; therefore look to't, be rowel'd be times.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I slight your opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, mark the end on't, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Nurse with water and Nibby.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, my Mistress presents her service to you, and desires you to be civil to her water, and use it with as much modesty as you may; for I assure you her Virginwater
was never exposed to publick view before.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Pray give it the stranger.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By no means, Gentlemen, I must have your opinions first. Nurse, art thou true to me?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: By my little life it's my own water, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: By my great life I'l marry thee to morrow then: but Nurse, when I wink at you, you must own the water to be yours.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I'l do it, dear Doctor.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Here is dangerous water, it does not shew the three Regents, neither is here colour, substance, perspicuity, darkness, contents, or smell.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Therefore the Urin being obstructed, must needs flye back upon the parts, as to the stomach in vomitings, to the belly in Dropsies.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Or to the head in Frensies, here we find plain madness. 'Slife I itch most terribly, this fellow sure can conjure.

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: The Cow-itch works, he is at it already.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come on, let me see the water; hum, ha, here is no madness, nor the least sign on't: Come hither, Sir; is your daughter married?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, Sir; why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Then I say she is a baggage, she had a chid lately, and counterfeits madness to keep the knowledge on't from you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beseech you believe not this scandalous Doctor: Sir, I'l have you punisht for this defamation: my daughter had a child you wretch?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come you'r a weak old man. I say again, that she that made this water has had a child lately, therefore let search be made to find it out.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: You will do well to examine it, for 'tis possible it may not be her water; for Doctors have had such tricks put on 'em ere now: this itching makes me mad.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But they can put no such tricks upon me, for my judgement cannot fail me; therefore I say look to't, for there's a child in the case.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Call all my servants; where's my daughters women? here must be treachery, and Nurse you must need know it.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Sir, I do know it indeed, and I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What has my daughter had a child then?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: No, Sir, but you know I have had one.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But the Doctor says, she that made the water has had a child.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: The Doctor says very true, for 'tis my water, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I was sure I could not be deceived.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Are you sure you speak truth, Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: By my little life do I, Mrs. Nibby can witness.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Nurse speaks very true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why did you so bold a thing as this, Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: If you'l have the truth, I did it to find out which would prove the ablest Doctor, and the stranger it seems is the Doctor of Doctors i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I believe he is, for ever since he felt my pulse, my back has play'd the Divel.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Worthy, Sir, I once more heartily crave your pardon, and must acknowledge you an able and faithful Gentleman: and Doctors I beseech your leaves to make use of this worthy stranger, as to the cure of my child.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: He must cure me too, for the vengeance has got into my back parts.

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: Sir, we consent, and think you have made a worthy choice. so we take our leaves, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, I hope you'l stay and see our way of practice; alas we cure madness with as much ease as, you do feavers, and meerly with humoring them.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I believe every word he says.

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: 'Tis well you'r convinced. O brave Cow-itch! pray, Sir, let your child be brought forth that we may dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Go Nurse prepare her quickly.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: She is ready, Sir,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Stirquilutio, go get me a Parsons Cassock.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why so, Sir? why so?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Because, Sir, you saw in her madness she phansied my Apothecary, my Operator to be Leander, and was much in love with him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She was so to my grief, but what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, if she take him for Leander again, you shall see how finely I'l fool her into her wits again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Here she comes.

div.stage: Enter Olinda, Nibby, Nurse and Servants.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: What is all the world got together? then I hope I shall find Leander amongst them.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Again Leander? a pox on him, who knows him, or ever saw him?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: None of your houshold, we have only heard well of him, and I believe she never saw him but at Church.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Like enough, that's one o'th' ends people go thither for: I'l take warning how I ever send my child to Church again.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Are you Leander, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Say I, say I, Doctor.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: I am Leander, Madam, at your service, if my back would give me leave.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Thou Leander, Beast? why thou shruggest as if thou wert lousie and wanted a clean shirt: O Doctor Divel have I catcht you, where's my Leander? find him, or I'l tear thee into Air.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here, here is your Leander, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: O you Divel, would you put a false Leander upon me? find me out the right, or I'l throw thee head-long to that dismal place prepared for Doctors.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here, here, Madam, is your right Leander.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: I, this is he indeed, now I thank you Doctor: nay, Sir. I'l take a course with you; why Leander, would you torment me with your absence thus?

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: It was not my fault, heaven knows, it was your cruel father kepe me from you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why raskal Apothecary? why say you so, you Villain?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis you are mad: Gentlemen Doctors, you saw how fine and calm she began to be upon humoring her: 'tis you that keeps her mad, I'l justifie it.
