sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, I have done, I have done; but here is something here that will not be removed.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I'l fetter you from running; Doctor, get me a Parson; does none of these grave men belong to th' Clergy?

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Run, run and fetch me one, they'r never i'th' way when they should do good.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Stirquilutio, put on the Parsons Coat quickly: Madam have patience, the Parson will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why so? why so Doctor? why so?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: To bring your child to her self again, ask these Doctors else.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Nay, no doubt they are right, Sir, if you obstruct them not; I must have his opinion for my disease too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Look you, here is the Parson, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olin.
Doct.
sp.p: No, no, by no means; you must not know old man your daughters to be married.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay Doctor, Doctor, no jesting with marriage.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why are you jealous of my Operator? Alas poor wretch! why, Gentlemen, the man has a wife and four children.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Has he, and art thou sure of that, Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, Sir, before these Gentlemen, if I speak false, degrade me of the dignity of a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I believe you, and am satified, and now I am as light and airy as a boy.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Who will be my father, and give me to Leander? I have a mind to this grave Gentlemaan; do you refuse me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, no, no, Madam; go and give her, Sir, go: bless us all, you see what a raging fit she had like to have faln into.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I, but I do not like, I do not know, I do not like, I do not know what to say to it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The Divel's in you, have forgot the fellow's married?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I had forgot, I had forgot, in troth I should laugh to see her thus recovered; why Gentlemen, is not this a strange way to cure madness?

sp.speaker: 3 Doct.
sp.p: It is so, Sir; but it seems they have the experience, the practical part, and truly it seems rational.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if we can but get her to sleep, in the belief that she is married to Leander, my life for yours she wakes i'th' morning in her right senses.

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: And sure this back will put me into my wrong senses.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I laugh to think, poor Girl, how she'l be cozen'd into her wits again.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Master, as I live, they'r married in earnest; I'l be sworn, with the very same words that I and my husband was.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let them alone, 'tis all but jest, Nurse; why the Apothecary's married, fool, and has four children.

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: 'Tis true that he is married, but no four children, Sir; but we will have four and four to that Girl.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: What shall we have but eight Leander?

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: Fiftie, fiftie Sons to vie with Priam; besides Girls shall be reckon'd but as by-blows.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Fiftie besides Girls? when shall a poor woman get such a husband?

sp.speaker: Hur. Olin.
sp.p: Now, Sir, we both crave your blessing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well said Apothecary, thou acts it to the life, i'faith: Gentlemen Doctors does he not do it well?

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: I shall do it better yet; Nurse make a Sack-posset, and let's to bed presently.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, no, no, no, Nurse, no going to bed, there you over act it Pothecary.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Sir, he is no Apothecary, but real Leander, and my lawful husband; therefore we must of necessity go to bed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why Doctor, this Girl is stark mad still.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No indeed, she speaks sensibly; what would you have a young woman do but go to bed when she's is married?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why Doctor, thou over acts thy part too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, this is neither Apothecary, Operator, nor Hurnatio, but very Leander; neither is this his man Stirquilutio, but his Brother, and a Minister in orders, who has lawfully made 'em man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How Villain! didst not thou say he was married and had four children, and bid me degrade thee of the dignitie of a Doctor, if it were not so.

sp.speaker: Doct.
All.
sp.p: How a Farrier!

sp.speaker: 2 Doct.
sp.p: Did not I tell you he must be a cheat.

sp.speaker: Hur.
sp.p: You have found him so, 'tis much that a Doctor weded to Rules and Method should be cozen'd by a Farrier; for you have no disease, 'twas onely a little Cow-itch put down your back.

sp.speaker: 2. Doct.
sp.p: A pex upon you, and all your cheats.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O this cursed Farrier, this cursed Villain, then you are not mad, Ladie?

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: No, Sir, neither was I mad or dumb, but counterfeited both to cozen the Squire and you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And you, Sir, were Leander, when you brought me the Letter from Leander?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: And you told me that Leander would steal my daughter, and gave me good counsel to look to her?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I did so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Twas good counsel if I could have taken it: that cursed Letter feigned from Leander cozen'd me, that got them credit with me, spite of my jealousie: thou art a pretty fellow, I confess, but the most impudent and audacious Villain, to marry my Child against my will, and before my face too, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Do you think I'd have been married but in my Fathers presence? not for all the world.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: 'Twas love forc'd us to make this shift, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A pox of love, for that's the end on't: did not I tell thee all along that thou wouldst cozen me?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You did so, Sir, but love can take no warning.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: For my revenge, I'l to bed, and fall desperately sick, make my will, and dye, and leave thee ne'er a groat, that thou and thy issue may starve and perish.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Fear not Leander, when this fit is over, he's to be reconciled, fear not.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Gentlemen Doctors, I hope 'tis no disparagement to you, that a poor Farrier, by a combination with Nurse, has cured a mad woman.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: • but w ••• e is my reward for it?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 Nurse, if thou wilt accept of a Farrier instead of a Doctor, I'l love thee still.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A pox on you for me, my heart is so set upon the white Periwig, that I shall ne'er be my own woman again.

div.stage: Enter Jarvis, Isabel, and many Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Where is my Master, here is witness enough now, that he is no Doctor, but a drunken Farrier; these are all his Neighbours, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I confess I am a Farrier, they all know it too; but can my Neighbours bear witness thou'rt no Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No, but here is witness that I am thy Wife, and that I am not mad.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'l own that too, thou art my wife, and not mad; nay, more than that, I'l go home and live with thee.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Well, I'l give you a Pension of fifty pounds a year, for the good service you did me in your raign of Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
Ger.
sp.p: Save the Squire, save the Squire, save the poor Squire.

div.stage: The Scene opens, and the Squire is discover'd hanging in a cradle.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.p: Is not that the Squires voice?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Yes, and 'tis high time to let him down now, open, open; come Squire, will you quit your interest in your Mistress now to be set free?

sp.speaker: Sqr.
sp.p: I, with all my heart, and the Divel take her to boot; I have hung so long i'th' Air, that the houshold [Let him down. took me for Mahome's Tomb, and paid my worship with their Piss-pots out of the Garret, I thank 'em.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: I caused it to be done.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I was joyned with her in commission of the member Vessels.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: But Squire, since you ha' lost your Mistress, what think you of marrying the wilde Irish Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Sqr.
sp.p: Who, Madam Pogamihone, I'l marry my mothers Sow first.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But Squire, when shall you and I fight another Duel?

sp.speaker: Sqr.
sp.p: Sir, if I were a man that were given to quarrelling, as sometimes they say in my drink I am; I'd have you know that I am able to beat, and cudgel, half a dozen such fellows as you are, I and make you creep under the Tables and Joyntstools, Sir; nay, I could cudgel you under a Candle-stick, Sir; that is, if I were a man that were given to quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I am very happy that you are a man not give to quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Sqr.
sp.p: So you are, Sir; but if I were given to quarrelling, here's a leg that is four and twenty inches about, that's three inches more than any of the Kings Cables, Sir; and I'd have you know, Sir; that I am able not onely to kick you down stairs, but kick you up stairs again, Sir; still that is, if my leg were given to kicking, or I to quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, we are all blest, that your leg of four and
twenty inches about is not given to kicking. Nurse, let the Sack-posset be made: In the interim we'l dance, and have the song of Arthur o' Bradley, where Christopher carried the custard.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And bartle the Beef and the Mustard.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Come my Olinda, let us in and prove
The sweet Rewards, due to our vertu's Love.

sp.speaker: Othen.
sp.l: I, I, to bed, you now need fear no Proctor,
But thank your Farrier cudgel'd to a Doctor.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: YOu that are Learn'd, expect honour for it;
We that are unlearn'd, slight and abhor it:
The Rich does look with scorn upon the Poor,
But give no Alms; the Beggar scorns you more.
Thus does the wretch your wealth disdain; nay worse,
For each proud look, the Beggar gives a curse:
But give him Alms, as I believe 'tis rare,
The Beggar gratefully returns his Pray'r.
So when the Vnlearn'd, by the learn'd improve,
They'l give them honour for their learned Love:
But stead of that, the Vnlearn'd they indite,
And proudly ask us how we dare to write?
We humbly answer our Inditement thus,
If Poetry be Fancie, the right's in us;
For you with Authors are so deeply read,
Invention has no room in learned head;
Borrowing what you read, and Authors citing,
Is your invention, and your writing.
Now th' illiterate are for fancie bent,
Having no learning, they must needs invent.
Thus Poetry is ours to inherit
As much as yours with your learned merit;
For as Quakers preach, we write, by th' spirit.
